title: teachers accused obstructing online study
story: Teachers have been accused of “blocking” children’s lockdown learning by citing union guidelines which say they should not conduct any online lessons which made them feel “uncomfortable”.The UK’s biggest teaching union, the National Education Union (NEU), has told its members that online lessons should be kept to “a minimum” and that they “cannot be expected to carry out routine marking or grading” of pupils’ work while schools are closed.The advice document published by the NEU adds that teachers should not live-stream lessons from home or do any video calls with pupils unless in “exceptional circumstances”.When parents who have complained about the lack of school work during lockdown, they have been told by headteachers that their hands are tied because of the opposition they have come against from the unions.One headteacher from Brighton told The  that he had hoped that teachers would produce a couple of online lessons each week, either live or pre-recorded videos, to keep children motivated and engaged.“Some teachers say that they are not willing to do it and that you can’t make them because the unions say they don’t have to,” he said.“There is not a huge amount I can do if I am honest. You could try and enforce it but you would never get very far, they would just down tools and say ‘you can’t force me’.”Marking and grading work is also important to keep children motivated, the headteacher said, adding: “I don’t really understand what the unions have against that.  If you are not marking the work, children won’t see the point of doing it.  “At the end of the day, children should be at the forefront of our thinking. This is not a one off, it’s a national emergency, you would think the unions would be a bit more understanding of that.”The NEU has issued two sets of guidelines for distance teaching and learning during the coronavirus pandemic, one for primary teachers and another for secondary teachers.“Teachers should not live-stream lessons from their homes, nor engage in any video-calling unless in exceptional circumstances, with the parent,” the primary school guidelines said.“Online lessons are not desirable for primary children as the teacher-pupil interaction is not easily replicated.”  Meanwhile, the secondary school advice document states: “If schools have systems set up for online lessons, these should be kept to a minimum as the interaction needed between teacher and pupils in school is high and cannot be easily replicated for a young audience, even at KS4 level.“Any school which carries out online lessons must have protocols in place to protect staff and safeguard pupils, and no teacher should be expected to carry out any online teaching with which they feel uncomfortable or in the absence of agreed protocols.”  One parent, who complained to her child’s school about the lack of work, said that she found the answer that teachers were refusing to set work online “infuriating”.  “Parents are desperately trying to struggle with working from home,” she said. “I found the fact that its unions blocking it to be really shocking.  Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the NEU, defended the guidelines and said that his members are working “flat out” to support students.The guidelines are aimed at managing the workload and stress of children, parents and teachers, he said, adding that they are “not about preventing learning”.  Mr Courtney said: “Arrangements for online learning must also protect teachers' and childrens' privacy and ensure children are kept safe while online. The NEU is supporting teachers and families to do the best they can with the resources available to them.  “We are suggesting ways of providing creative packs for younger pupils, and access to real books and printed resources - because online learning simply is not accessible for many pupils, too many have limited access to laptops or quiet space in which to view lessons at set times of day.”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: us uk intelligence agencies examining report mobile phone data
story: US and British intelligence agencies are reportedly examining mobile phone data suggesting there could have been an emergency shutdown in October at the Wuhan Institute of Virology.According to a report, obtained by NBC News, there was no mobile phone activity in a high-security part of the Chinese laboratory complex from Oct 7 to Oct 24. Previously, there had been consistent use of mobile phones.The report, carried out by private experts, suggested there may have been a hazardous event, specifically at the institute's National Biosafety Laboratory, between Oct 6 and Oct 11.Analysis of mobile phone data from the area surrounding the institute also suggested roadblocks were in place between Oct 14 and Oct 19.Experts urged caution over the report, suggesting it may be based on only limited commercially available mobile phone data, and that there could be other reasons for varying levels of phone usage.However, the document could be what Donald Trump was referring to when the president recently said he had seen evidence giving him a high degree of confidence the pandemic began accidentally at the Wuhan laboratory.The prevailing theory is that the virus originated in bats and crossed over to humans at a market in Wuhan.But US intelligence agencies continue to investigate the Wuhan laboratory and Mike Pompeo, the US secretary of state, has said there is a significant amount of evidence.It was unclear which private organisation carried out the leaked analysis of the mobile phone location data.But the 24-page report suggested it supports the release of Covid-19 at the Wuhan Institute of Virology and that the pandemic began earlier than previously thought. The first confirmed case so far in China was on Nov 17.The document was obtained by NBC News in London. In addition to intelligence agencies it has been seen by the US Senate intelligence committee.Several days ago Marco Rubio, the Republican senator who sits on the committee, wrote on Twitter: Would be interesting if someone analyzed commercial telemetry data at &amp near Wuhan lab from Oct-Dec 2019.If it shows dramatic drop off in activity compared to previous 18 months it would be a strong indication of an incident at lab &amp of when it happened.China has denied that the virus escaped from the Wuhan laboratory.US officials said they had previously looked at other reports, also based on publicly available mobile phone data, suggesting a shutdown at the Wuhan laboratory.They went on to examine their own data, including satellite images, and could not establish that there had been a temporary closure at the Wuhan lab, deciding that the suggestion was inconclusive.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ancient breed sheepdog front line efforts bring wolves back
story: An ancient breed of sheepdog is being recruited to protect livestock as part of a campaign to encourage the return of wolves to the mountains of Portugal.Dozens of Serra de Estrela mountain dog puppies are to be trained as sheepdogs to help farmers ward off attacks from wolves, as the species makes a comeback.The idea is that shepherds who have dogs that can fight off wolf attacks are less likely to want to kill the predators.The project, organised by the conservation organisation Rewilding Europe, involves up to 100 Estrela mountain dogs being entrusted to farmers in the Serra de Montemuro region of northern Portugal, where wolves are making a comeback.In Portugal there are around 300 endangered Iberian wolves – a sub-species of the grey wolf – and conservationists want to expand the population, while trying to manage any conflict with landowners.That is where the dogs come in - if introduced to sheep flocks when they are puppies, the powerful breed forges strong protective bonds.The dogs were used by shepherds until the early 20th century, when shooting and poisoning came to be regarded as a quicker and easier way of combating the wolf threat.The wolf has been a protected species in Portugal since 1988 but that has not prevented many animals from being killed.Between 1999 and 2008, for instance, 64 wolves were killed, according to a report by the National Institute for Conservation of Forests. Of those, 21 died in traffic accidents, 11 were trapped with snares, 10 were shot, three were poisoned, two were strangled and one died from an infection.“This is a breed that has been used in the region for centuries,” Deli Saavedra, a regional manager for Rewilding Europe, told The .“The wolf population in the region is small and scattered at the moment but when it grows there will be the potential for conflict. The dogs are big animals and they are capable of protecting the sheep.”The conservationists are also trying to boost the number of roe deer in the region, to provide the wolves with a source of wild prey rather than livestock. “If wolves have a choice, they always go for wild animals rather than domestic animals,” said the ecologist.The first Estrela mountain dog puppy to undergo training is called Leão, meaning lion in Portuguese.He is just a few months old now but once fully-grown, at 18 months, he will spend his days and nights protecting sheep from wolves.“The target is to eventually embed 100 dogs with flocks and herds in the project area,” said Sara Aliácar, from Rewilding Portugal.“A shepherd with Serra da Estrela dogs can guard against wolf predation far more effectively than one without.”With large tracts of the region in north-eastern Portugal abandoned by farmers over the years, Rewilding Europe wants to return hundreds of thousands of hectares to their natural state.That would encourage the return not just of the wolf but other signature species such as the Iberian lynx, black vulture and imperial eagle.The organisation is promoting rewilding projects across Europe, from Italy’s central Apennines to the Rhodope Mountains of Bulgaria and the Southern Carpathians in Romania.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: consider possibility coronavirus isnt actually anyones fault
story: Our political culture fails to acknowledge that governments working with incomplete information will, inevitably, make mistakesWe know more about the coronavirus than we did two months ago. We have a clearer idea of how people get infected and of who is most at risk. It is starting to look, for example, as though outdoor transmissions are rare. It is also starting to look as though certain groups of people are unlikely to suffer severe symptoms. Women seem to be less susceptible than men, thin people than overweight people, young people than old people and so on. Had we known at the start of March what we know now, we would doubtless have done things differently.There would have been more emphasis on the shielding of hospitals and care homes, less on preventing casual outdoor meetings. There would, I suspect, also have been less pressure to close schools: each new study adds to the evidence that children are neither at risk themselves nor likely to infect others.Governments working with incomplete information will, inevitably, make mistakes. But our entire political culture is based around denying this obvious truth.Everything is seen through the prism of imagined culpability. Each day, at the briefing, broadcast journalists pass up the chance to ask interesting questions about the spread of the disease, possible mutations or levels of immunity. Instead they line up to accuse ministers of changing their tune, failing to foresee some development, or saying the wrong thing.Behind such questions is the implicit assumption that the number of fatalities is primarily determined by government policy. But how likely is this? Might not other factors, such as population density, demographics or climate, matter more?We don’t like to admit it, of course. All human beings place themselves at the centre of the universe and, by extension, we overestimate the impact of all human behaviour.How coronavirus affects young and oldOur remote ancestors could not believe that plagues simply happened. Something as awful as a pestilence had to be someone’s fault. Perhaps the population at large had committed a sin, or perhaps it was all the fault of a religious minority or some other unpopular group.We like to imagine that we have outgrown such superstitions, but have we? Is our determination to apportion blame any more rational than our reluctance to buy Corona beer?Our leaders are well aware of our anthropocentrism: they know that they, rather than climate or geography, will get whatever praise or blame is going. So, understandably, they overreact. Politically, it is better to squander billions than to be accused of inaction.The longer the lockdowns endure, the more they take on a momentum of their own.We might not have closed schools knowing what we now know. But that is not the same thing as being able to reopen them once the status quo has shifted.Commentators talk about “a new normal” after the lockdown, but the horrible truth is that we have already normalised the restrictions. See how easily we accepted the formulation of five tests for the closures to end, rather than five tests for the closures to continue.Seven weeks ago, I wrote that the restrictions would be easier to impose than to lift. Though there may not be much correlation between the strictness of a lockdown and the spread of the disease, many of us are now primed to blame ministers for every fatality. It is not just the virus that is keeping the country locked down. It’s us.When allegations of rule-breaking were first levelled against Vote Leave, they were given wall-to-wall coverage. The BBC and Sky News considered them an immense scandal. The Observer gave Carole Cadwalladr a whole page to air her conspiracy theories. Channel 4 News actually devoted an entire hour-long programme to them. The dropping of the last of the cases this week, by contrast, received little attention.Obviously, there are a lot of other things going on at the moment. Even so, had the police decided to press charges, I suspect those media would have found space for it.What happened was terrifying. Two honest citizens, Alan Halsall, a likeable entrepreneur from Lancashire, and Darren Grimes, a young man from a council estate in County Durham, had their lives turned upside down by false accusations. For four years – think about that, four years – they were pursued by the Electoral Commission. They had to spend more in legal fees than they would have been fined had they actually been guilty. They lost months of productive time.And all for what? No one was suggesting that they had rigged the vote, let alone made any personal gain. Both were volunteers. At worst, they had filled in a bit of paperwork incorrectly.No action, of course, will be taken against their accusers. Their case will stand as a warning to anyone else who challenges the Establishment: this is what we can do to you. If you were still wondering why we need to overhaul our quango state, here is your answer.Coronavirus latest news: Boris Johnson doubles down on stay alert slogan as Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland reject itNHS waiting lists could double by autumn, amid fears service will be overwhelmedFrance urges vigilance in easing lockdown after clusters detected in low-infection &#39green&#39 areasCurfew introduced as coronavirus stalks the Navajo nation Coronavirus timeline: From a few cases in China to a global pandemicSocial distancing: What are the rules and how might they change?Revealed: Boris Johnson&#39s roadmap to ease lockdown and reopen schools and shopsEnd of lockdown timetable: When shops, offices, and public transport will reopen Boris Johnson&#39s lockdown speech: what time is it, what will he say, and how can I watch it?US Mother&#39s Day 2020: how the campaign was won – and why the woman behind it turned against her workWhen will the UK lockdown end? The four potential exit strategiesCoronavirus risk for young is &#39staggeringly low&#39, says UK&#39s top statisticianCoronavirus contact tracing app downloaded by just 40 per cent in Isle of Wight trialAncient breed of sheepdog in front-line of efforts to bring wolves back to PortugalThe Government&#39s plan for getting us back to workChurches may not be back to normal by end of the year, bishop warns&#39We should brace for pandemic&#39s second wave&#39, says South Korea&#39s presidentSamantha Cameron&#39s father mugged on his own estate, court hearsComment: Socialists and greens are determined to use this crisis to impose a dystopian &#39new normal&#39Three children have died from syndrome possibly linked to coronavirus, says New York governor We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: country by country rest world easing lockdown
story: For millions of people it is the moment they have longed for. After weeks of being confined to their homes and unable to work, study or simply enjoy themselves as normal, lockdowns are being lifted around the world.But while welcome, these moments are also fraught with danger, risking the potential of a second surge in coronavirus cases and more people succumbing to a disease which has already claimed more than 265,000 lives.Now, as Britain waits to hear from the Prime Minister how and when our lockdown will be lifted, all eyes are on those countries where social restrictions have been eased over the past few weeks.As infection rates have fallen schools have reopened in places like Denmark, shops allowed to trade in Austria and Germany and people have begun going back to work, even in Spain and Italy, two of the hardest hit countries.But it is not simply a case of returning to the kind of world we remember. Lifting lockdowns means retaining or adopting a complex set of social distancing measures to prevent an upsurge in infections, such as sitting apart from your classmates, face masks on public transport or distancing poles in museums.These measures will be closely monitored in Britain as it looks to those nations attempting the tightrope act of lifting the lockdown for pointers on how to end its own endurance test.Here The  looks at how restrictions are being eased as the virus recedes.Denmark became the first nation to ease restrictions when it reopened daycare centres, primary schools, small businesses and hairdressers on April 20th.More recently Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen announced that the spread of the virus had been brought under control, allowing the country to re-open by May 10.The decision to open primary schools meant a new set of rules for children: class sizes were cut by half and they have to wash their hands frequently, play in small groups and sit at desks at least two-metres apart.At the same time they are not allowed to bring toys from home and the school’s own toys and equipment has to be disinfected twice a day.Denmark’s R rate (the average number of infections caused by one infected person) did rise after easing the lockdown, but is still below the safe limit of 1.0 and there is as yet no sign of a second wave. Christian Wejse, of the department of infectious diseases at Aarhus University, said: “There are no signs whatsoever that the partial reopening has caused a bigger spread of infection. We are by no means home safe, but we have a really good starting point now to get the number of infected further down.”Austria was one of the first countries in Europe to ease restrictions when it allowed shops to reopen. More than three weeks on, there is still no sign of a second wave of infections according to the Austrian authorities.Restaurants and bars are to be allowed to reopen from the end of next week, along with religious services.As schools begin to go back this week classes are being ided in two to limit numbers, with one group taught from Monday to Wednesday, and a second on Thursday and Friday. The two groups will swap over each week.In Vienna, a socially distanced park has been built in the form of a maze. Each path is gated at entrance and exit and is 240cm away from other paths, allowing people to walk and exercise freely while being safely socially distanced.Germany took significant steps towards ending its lockdown this week, announcing that restaurants, pubs and hotels will be allowed to reopen.The Bundesliga football league is to resume from May 16, open air sport is once more permitted for the general public and Germans are allowed to entertain family and friends from up to two households.Classes are gradually resuming, with those facing exams given priority.Museums and zoos have already reopened, many with inventive new layouts to keep visitors apart. At the Brandenburg State Museum for Modern Art in Cottbus, southeast of Berlin, visitors in pairs can each take one end of a pole or ribbons exactly 1.5m long to keep their distance.The measures come with no sign of a second wave of infections more than two weeks after Germany began lifting its lockdown with the reopening of shops.With one of the highest death rates in the world - in part because of the way it counts fatalities - Belgium’s staggered reopening from this week is being closely watchedEmphasis is being placed on face masks. Shoppers are being advised to wear one and they are obligatory on public transport, where eating and drinking has been banned so people are not tempted to remove them.Masks are being sold from vending machines in train stations and anyone not wearing one faces a 250 euro fine. Local mayors have introduced rules demanding face masks are worn on certain streets which are too narrow or busy to ensure the 1.5 metre rule is respected. Masks are also mandatory if you are within 15 metres of a school at certain times. To meet demand, fabric shops have been given dispensation to open earlier than other shops, which must wait until May 11. Workers in Antwerp port have begun wearing smart wristbands that will tell them when they get too close to a colleague. Italy began easing its two-month lockdown on Monday, when the government allowed factories and construction sites to open up again after one of the strictest social distancing regimes in Europe.In a significant boost for morale people can go to the beach, but only to swim or run –not sunbathe. The same applies to parks, where Italians can walk or run but cannot stop for picnics.Shops are due to reopen on May 18, bars, restaurants and hairdressers on June 1, but schools will not open until September.In Alpine towns snow cannons have been used to spray disinfectant as a way of removing coronavirus from surfaces.From June 1, Phase Two of the reopening, train travellers must wear a mask and gloves, have a valid motive for travel and stay one metre from the other passengers. There is also disinfectant gel sanitizer available on the trains. These rules appear to be visibly posted in the larger urban train stations, but less so in the smaller cities. Buses are enforcing one way entry and exit rules, with face masks obligatory for passengers.In public places such as post offices and banks, every other chair in the waiting room has a sign saying don't sit here to keep people distanced. There are also taped lines on the floor suggesting people stand far back back from the counters.   After enduring a strict lockdown in which people were only recently allowed out for brief exercise almost all areas in Spain will enter the first of a three-phase exit plan on MondaySmall shops will be able to open and outdoor terrace bars can put out half the usual number of tables, though Madrid is offering to allow them to occupy more space where possible.Subway trains and buses in Spanish cities, including Madrid, have marked alternate seats as out of bounds to prevent people making contact with the person next to them, with standing room limited to two people per square metre.In phase two, indoor bars and restaurants will open with strict limits on numbers, as well as shopping centres, museums, cinemas and theatres, at one-third capacity.Hunting and fishing can resume in phase two, but bullfights are off limits until phase three, sometime in June, though promoters say it will not be worthwhile since each spectator must sit alone in a space of nine square metres.Also in phase three, beaches are due to reopen. Currently swimming and surfing are allowed, but not spending time on the sand. Portugal - which has had vastly lower infection and death rates than its neighbour after being quick off the mark to impose tough lockdown measures - is now into the first of a three-phase exit strategy, with small businesses having opened for customers on Monday, along with libraries, public offices and parks. Face masks are obligatory in covered public spaces, with gloves also encouraged. Phase two, from May 18, will see restaurants and cafés open at half capacity, as well as large stores, museums, galleries and monuments. Schools will reopen for pupils who have exams, with masks to be worn at all times. Crèches will also open for parents who need to use them.On June 1, all leisure options will be allowed to open, including gyms, hotels, malls, bars and nightclubs.A “good practices” guide for beachgoers is planned. Some beaches remain sealed off and out of bounds, while in other places people are being allowed to swim as an “inidual sport” now permitted along with fishing, golf and others.China - where Covid-19 first emerged - has been cautiously reopening its schools, with pupils across the country facing temperature checks at the gates and social distancing measures in the classroom.This week around 57,000 high school students with upcoming university entrance exams returned to class in Wuhan, the initial epicentre of the pandemic, where schools were closed in January.Arrival times were staggered and pupils wearing masks walked in single file to their desks, which were kept at least one metre apart.In Hangzhou, children at one elementary school have spent time decorating their own bespoke “social-distancing” hats which have metre-long wings to help them avoid getting too close to each other.Restaurants are also now open, although they are not as crowded as before the pandemic. Customers must have their temperature checked before entering and must have a green health code on an app which calculates their risk for Covid-19.On Friday China's top decision-making body gave the green light for cinemas, entertainment venues and sports facilities nationwide to shortly reopen after several months of closures.France will gradually start lifting restrictions on travel from May 11 as part of lockdown easing measures which rely on massive testing of suspected cases and their contacts.People will be able to travel up to 100km (62 miles) from home - up from just one kilometre currently - but only those with imperious family or professional reasons will be able to travel further.French borders will remain closed until 15 June at the earliest except for trans-border EU workers or European, including British, nationals with essential family or economic reasons, such as seasonal agriculture work.Masks will be compulsory in public transport on pain of a €135 fine. In Paris, only those with a form justifying professional or other essential reasons can travel during rush hour to avoid overcrowding.Some 100 million masks will be distributed to those who are sick, health staff and the vulnerable. Around a million pupils will return to classes next week in up to 85 percent of establishments, with priority given to health workers' children and those with special needs and difficulties.Secondary schools will remain shut in ‘red’ higher infection areas and only gradually opened elsewhere starting from May 18. Lycees. Lycees will remain shut nationwide until June at the earliest.Some 400,000 businesses will open but cafes, bars and restaurants will stay closed until at least June. Beaches will remain closed except if mayors and local officials agree otherwise. Dutch primary schools and childcare providers will reopen from May 11, with children allowed to play sports together as long as they remain 1.5 metres apart.Adults will also be allowed to to take part in sports as long as the game is outside and social distancing can be respected. But competitive matches are not allowed and neither is the use of shared changing rooms. Secondary schools will reopen from June 1. Vocational training schools will reopen for exams and practical training from June 15. People in contact based professions, such as driving instructors, alternative medicine practitioners and hairdressers can return to work but must stay 1.5 metres away from their clients.People on public transport are advised to use a face mask, which will become obligatory from June 1. Cafes and restaurants can reopen their outdoor seating provided the terrace is big enough to keep customers 1.5 metres apart and some establishments are trialling glass booths to keep diners safe.But cannabis cafes, sex clubs and brothels will stay closed until at least September 1 and will only reopen if coronavirus remains under control. New Zealand followed an 'eradication strategy' of shutting the country down early and keeping restrictions in place until it is sure community transmission has come to an end. The Level Four lock down announced when it hit 102 cases imposed significant restrictions on trade and movement and shut down schools and all domestic flights.People were instructed to stay at home in their “bubble” other than for essential personal movement.In less than two months the country is on a phased path to reopening, with May 4 marking its first day without any infection since it went into lockdown in March. It currently has two Covid-19 cases in hospital, none in ICU. They have lost 21 people to the virus.New Zealand has now moved to Level 3. This means people are still instructed to stay home in their bubble other than for essential personal movement, including to go to work, school if they have to, or for local recreation.Physical distancing of two metres outside home including on public transport, or one metre in controlled environments like schools and workplaces.People can reconnect with close family or bring in caregivers, or support isolated people as part of an extended bubble.Schools between years 1 to 10 and Early Childhood Education centres can open but will have limited capacity and children should learn at home if possible.People must work from home if possible. Businesses can open premises, but cannot physically interact with customers.Low-risk local recreation activities are allowed, but public venues are closed.New Zealand will move to the more relaxed Level 2 on Monday if “the disease is contained”, even if the risk of community transmission remains and “single or isolated cluster outbreaks” remain a possibility.In America, decisions about reopening are being taken by governors in each of the 50 states, creating a patchwork of differing rules across the country. Around half of the states are now partially reopening, mainly in the centre and south of the country. That includes ones run by both Republican and Democratic governors. States on the West coast, such as California and Washington which were hit early by coronavirus, and in the North East like New York and New Jersey still have lockdowns or restrictions in place.  Donald Trump has been the most prominent cheerleader for reopenings, repeatedly arguing that our country wasn't built to be shut down and warning of the economic consequences of prolonged lockdowns, while also urging safety.His administration published detailed guidance in mid-April that advised three phases for reopening which a state can progress through as the coronavirus outbreak fades away. However some states have ignored a key part of that advice - that they should only start loosening the rules once a downward trajectory of Covid-19 cases has been seen for 14 days. Many other states in the US are watching Georgia, which has forged ahead.It has already reopened for gyms, bowling alleys, cinemas, nail salons and massage therapists.Restaurants can open as long as there are only 10 diners per 500 square feet of floor space, and disposable menus are used.Shopping malls have reopened in some states including Georgia, Florida and Texas. They are limited to 25 per cent capacity and have seen few customers.South Korea is set to reopen schools next week for the first time in two months, starting with senior high school pupils preparing for university entrance exams. Schools will be required to carry out regular disinfection and temperature checks and to rearrange seating to help students keep their distance.South Korea has never been fully locked down. The resumption of education follows a steady easing of social distancing rules that has seen people return to shopping malls, golf courses and parks and employees swap work from home for office life again.But the slow return to normalcy has not been without risk. Alarm bells began ringing once again on Friday after it emerged that an infected 29-year-old man visited five night clubs and bars in the capital, Seoul. At least 14 more cases have now been linked to the same patient.The government has now requested bars and clubs to voluntarily suspend business for a month and to make sure that entry logs for visitors to public places are properly filled out for tracking purposes.Life in Israel has almost returned to normal, with prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu celebrating a self-declared victory over Covid-19.Hairdressers, hardware and electrical shops and restaurants have reopened, although the latter are takeaway-only. Mr Netanyahu has credited Israel's early decision to close its borders for its comparatively low mortality and infection rates compared to the rest of the Middle East. The country’s aviation chiefs are exploring the possibility of a medical passport system where citizens are allowed to travel abroad after undergoing a 45-minute coronavirus test. And Israeli scientists believe that analysing excrement in sewers will allow them to detect coronavirus hotspots and prevent a second wave.Additional reporting by Nick Squires, Justin Huggler, James Crisp, James Badcock, Nicola Smith, Giovanni Torre, Henry Samuel, James Rothwell, Marcus Parekh, Nick Allen and Lya CaiMore from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: end lockdown timetable when shops pubs transport offices reopen
story: Boris Johnson is planning to address the nation again today at 7pm, when he will set out an exit plan for how Britain will gradually leave lockdown.While details of phase two of Britain's response to the coronavirus pandemic will only be made public at the end of this weekend, there are already some indications of how different elements of society are set to reopen.Guidance is expected to be issued by the Government on how shops can reopen safely, which would include physical distancing measures and could also extend to separate exits and entrances.All stores deemed non-essential were ordered to close when lockdown measures came into effect on March 23. These included clothing shops, bookstores, hairdressers, bed and breakfasts, and indoor and outdoor markets.Shops that have been exempt from the Government's ban are food retailers, pharmacies, hardware stores, corner shops, petrol stations, shops in hospitals, post offices, banks, newsagents, launderettes, and pet shops.Garden centres are to open this week, the Prime Minister is expected to announce. The centres will be allowed to open their doors on Wednesday while still abiding by social distancing rules.The hardware business B&ampQ, which was deemed an essential retailer, last month reopened 75 of its stores after plans were agreed to safeguard customers and staff.The measures adopted by B&ampQ offer some indication on the guidelines that will be issued across the sector, including strict limits of the numbers of customers in a store at any given time, designated queuing areas, and two-metre markers in order to remind customers of the need for social distancing.The British Retail Consortium has compiled a set of suggested rules which include having extra barriers, encouraging customers to shop alone, keeping changing rooms closed, and the use of protective screens at the tills.Brands are also considering introducing sanitation stations and even portable sinks, so  that people can wash their hands when they enter a store. Alex Baldock, the Dixons Carphone boss, has devised zero-contact stores, which will have drive-through-style pickup points for goods. The British Retail Consortium has submitted a report to Government recommending that if non-essential shops reopen, changing rooms should stay closed and in-store seating and services – such as advice, personal shopping or nail bars – should be limited.Retailers and unions have put aside long-standing differences to join forces, with the intention of restarting the retail sector as soon as possible without threats of industrial action.John Lewis, the department store chain, is due to open some of its stores from mid-May, while Associated British Foods - the boss of Primark’s owner - said notice of between two and four weeks will be required to help the industry get up and running again.Retailers that are currently trading have taken measures outside and inside stores, introducing plexiglass screens at tills and limiting numbers both in store and in socially-distanced warehousing operations.A glimpse of the new normal for working in offices is given by seven separate government documents obtained by this newspaper which give draft guidelines for opening shopping centres, hotels, factories, and offices.Recommendations for offices include plexiglass screens being installed between desks and the requirement for workers to sit back-to-back or side-to-side, rather than face-to-face. The Prime Minister is also set to announce that companies will be asked to provide face coverings for staff who are required back at work.The documents also stipulate that lifts should be half-empty, hot-desking is to be abolished for the foreseeable future, and the sharing of equipment such as pens and staplers will be banned.Employees will still be encouraged to work from home if this is possible, with employers expected to have regular communication with workers about their mental and physical wellbeing. In fact, Britons could be given a legal right to work from home to ensure that they are not forced to go back to workplaces after the lockdown under plans being considered in Whitehall.For those who do come into the workplace, the nine-to-five work day will end for the foreseeable future, as employers stagger arrival and departure times to reduce crowding.Office spaces are set to be reconfigured to enable adequate social distancing, with screens and floor markings used to ensure that staff stay two metres apart from one another.The document urges employers to continue to carry out meetings remotely where possible, as well as providing additional entry points, plus extra parking and bike-raking facilities to discourage the use of public transport.New rules as Italians have gone back to work have sparked confusion and frustration, which bosses will be keen to avoid as Britain gradually reopens for business.Public transport capacity and usage has been severely reduced throughout the lockdown. The London Underground has been operating a reduced service, with 40 Underground stations closing which do not sit on the intersections of Tube lines, and the Night Tube service was suspended on March 19 before the full lockdown came into place.“London will get through these extraordinarily challenging times and ensuring the capital’s critical workers can move around the city will be crucial,” said Mayor of London Sadiq Khan.Mr Johnson is expected to issue more guidance on face coverings after a survey by the rail and road watchdog, Transport Focus, found that more than half of commuters (51 per cent) would not be happy using trains and buses again unless the Government mandated the wearing of face masks.In a poll of 2,000 passengers, carried out earlier this month, 83 per cent of passengers said they also wanted hand sanitiser made available on vehicles as well as train stations and bus stops, and 62 per cent said they would not venture back onto public transport unless effective social-distancing measures are in place.The Transport Secretary Grant Shapps on May 9 announced a £2 billion package to increase cycling and walking capacity across the United Kingdom, a response to the new difficulties that commuters will face getting to work during the pandemic.The programme will be published early next month and aims to double the amount of people cycling by 2025, while also encouraging more people walking to work.Measures announced include pop-up bike lines, wider pavements, and streets that will exclusively be for the use of bicycles and buses.“Whilst it’s crucial that we stay at home, when the country does get back to work we need to ask those people to carry on cycling or walking and for them to be joined by many others as well,” Mr Shapps said.Defence Secretary Ben Wallace has said that masks are currently being stockpiled for use by the public, and that face coverings on public transport could be encouraged in order to reassure the public that it is safe to go back to work. Masks and distancing measures are two of the measures that could be made compulsory on public transport.British Transport Police may need to maintain a presence at station entrances to ensure crowd control and social distancing at the busiest times, while companies are likely to have to stagger their working days to avoid a single rush hour.The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) has suggested that the use of public transport during peak time should be discouraged, in order to reduce congestion and lessen the risk of infection spreading.Examples would be to increase the relative price of commuting at peak times on the London tube and bus network, or to suspend the London congestion charge for drivers, it said.As things stand, pubs and restaurants - with the exception of restaurants which are currently operating solely in a takeaway capacity - will be among the last spaces to reopen.It is not currently possible when this will be, but industry estimates range from July through to winter or even early 2021.Restrictive measures on reopening are likely to include fewer tables, limits on customer numbers, shortened opening hours, more local produce, and restricted menus.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association (BBPA), said: Currently there is no clear indication as to when pubs will be able to open again. As it stands, the Government guidance is clear and pubs will continue to adhere to that.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: public health bureaucrats must face reckoning catastrophic coronavirus
story: In the UK, there was no discussion about testing and tracing – the key failure of PHE that allowed the virus to spread unbeknownstThe responses of different governments to coronavirus have been largely characteristic. China censored whistle-blowers and allowed the virus to spread across the globe before soldering apartment doors shut. Taiwan, Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong introduced border measures and tested, traced, and isolated. They avoided mass outbreaks. President Trump shut the border to China but did little else. Australia also shut its border, but went further with testing.Britain’s Sir Humphries are supposed to be well-educated and competent. This crisis, however, has proven otherwise. The bureaucracy failed to prevent an infectious disease outbreak and tens of thousands have died. The “best and brightest” bungled the biggest threat since the Second World War.This was not for a lack of resources. We spend billions on public health – but infectious diseases get half as much money as obesity. It was not a failure of imagination, either. A pandemic has been the UK’s number one official threat for years. Nor was there a lack of planning. On paper, the UK ranked among the top countries in the world for pandemic preparedness.So what went wrong?The Cygnus Exercise report leaked last week is revealing. Cygnus was a three-day simulated influenza pandemic led by Public Health England (PHE) in 2016. It involved hundreds of people across local authorities, departments and the NHS.What is most insightful about the exercise’s findings is not what it discovered but the omissions. These supposed top public health officials had almost no foresight about the challenges we would face in 2020.There was no discussion about testing and tracing – the key failure of PHE that allowed the virus to spread unbeknownst. This slowed our response and likely cost lives. PPE was mentioned just once, in a discussion about distribution points, not huge supply chain issues. Border measures to prevent a virus entering the country were not considered.Impact of behavioural and social interventionsThe generals were fighting the last war: an influenza outbreak like the H1N1 virus of 2009, rather than a novel coronavirus like Covid-19. This is despite relatively recent outbreaks of coronaviruses including Sars and Mers. So although enough antiviral cold and flu tablets for half the population were stockpiled, they have proven useless.Operation Cygnus did show some foresight, but the operation’s stark warnings about the ability of the care sector to deal with a pandemic were never passed on. So when Covid-19 hit, the NHS activated its pandemic rapid discharge protocols in March like clockwork, discharging thousands out of hospitals into care homes. Few were tested, bringing the virus into contact with the most vulnerable.We cannot make the same mistakes again. Parts of the media have blandly focused on personalities: who was at what meeting? This distracts from the heart of the problem: the catastrophic failure of the bureaucracy to prepare for an outbreak.Retribution for the sake of retribution may be emotionally satisfying. But if we are to avoid the same fate in future, the system responsible for this mess must face a reckoning.Matthew Lesh is the head of research at the Adam Smith InstituteCoronavirus latest news: Boris Johnson doubles down on stay alert slogan as Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland reject itCurfew introduced as coronavirus stalks the Navajo nation Coronavirus timeline: From a few cases in China to a global pandemicSocial distancing: What are the rules and how might they change?Revealed: Boris Johnson&#39s roadmap to ease lockdown and reopen schools and shopsEnd of lockdown timetable: When shops, offices, and public transport will reopen Boris Johnson&#39s lockdown speech: what time is it, what will he say, and how can I watch it?US Mother&#39s Day 2020: how the campaign was won – and why the woman behind it turned against her workWhen will the UK lockdown end? story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Chinese space agency hopes capsule can one day carry six astronauts into spaceAn experimental Chinese spacecraft has returned to Earth&nbspafter&nbspa mysterious malfunction.The craft is part of a&nbspmission to increase Beijing’s presence in space&nbsp–&nbspits own version of the&nbspInternational Space Station is part of&nbspthe plans.The craft was launched from a new heavy-lift carrier rocket, the Long March 5B, from&nbspHainan&nbspisland on Tuesday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt then orbited around Earth before dropping into the atmosphere and landing back in China as planned, according to state media.But its mission had been hit by a mysterious malfunction with a “flexible and inflatable cargo return capsule” that was being tested as part of the launch, and which China gave no further information on.&nbspThe China Manned Space Agency has said only that it operated abnormally during&nbspreentry&nbspon Wednesday and data is being&nbspanalysed.Chinese spacecraft sends first ever pictures taken on far side of moonThe spacecraft’s mission did not include any crew, but reportedly was a test of a capsule that could one day carry Chinese astronauts into space. It is said to be&nbspan improvement on the&nbspShenzhou&nbspcapsule based on the former Soviet Union’s Soyuz model and can carry six astronauts instead of three.The spacecraft was flying stably in a “highly elliptical orbit, with the power supply, measurements and control links normal”, the official China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation had said earlier, following reports of the issues, according to the official Xinhua News Agency.China is working on a permanent orbiting station after being excluded from the International Space Station, largely because of US&nbspobjections.Beijing previously&nbsplaunched an experimental space station and plans four crewed and four cargo missions to finish a permanent space station within about two years.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. No problem, just download the program.“Grimes explains how to pronounce baby name X Æ A-12Elon Musk explains why he’s selling all his possessionsElon Musk says video calls will ‘definitely’ be coming to Tesla carsAsked how long it would take for his firm to develop technology advanced enough to do it, Musk said between five and 10 years, “if the development continues to accelerate”.Musks extraordinary prediction came at the end of an eventful couple of weeks for the technology entrepreneur.Earlier this week, his pop star girlfriend Grimes gave birth to their first child, before leaving many fans confused over the boy’s name.It came just days after a tweet from Musk about Tesla’s share price saw the company value temporarily plummet $14bn (£11.2bn).“Tesla stock price too high imo,” Musk said, kicking off a bizarre series of tweets in which he claimed he was planning to sell “almost all” of his physical possessions.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New target of capacity of 200,000 tests a day set by governmentAfter the government claimed to have met its goal of providing 100,000 coronavirus tests a day by the end of&nbspApril – this has been contested amid accusations of data manipulation – a new target for May has now been set.As authorities prepare to ease certain lockdown measures, Downing Street announced that it is aiming to increase capacity to 200,000 tests a day by the end of the month.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe government has acknowledged that large-scale testing and contact tracing will be vital to ending the lockdown, having promised in the earlier stages of the pandemic&nbspto eventually deliver 250,000 tests a day.This pledge has since been watered down, with Downing Street stressing that the latest target set by the PM relates only to testing capacity and not to the number of tests actually carried out.Since health secretary Matt Hancock announced that more than 122,000 tests had been carried out on the final day of April, the daily testing figure has frequently dropped below the 100,000 mark since.Under the latest government guidelines, anyone over 65 years old with symptoms of Covid-19 will be able to get tested for the virus.Care home residents and staff will also be able to access tests,&nbspeven if they do not have symptoms, as well as asymptomatic NHS patients and staff.People who leave their homes to work, and are displaying signs of coronavirus, are similarly eligible for testing.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: jupiter image picture storms great red spot space hubble gemini observatory
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Pictures are some of the sharpest infrared images of Jupiter ever taken from the EarthScientists have got lucky with new pictures of Jupiter that could help solve the mystery of its swirling storms.The new images used special techniques to allow the researchers to take some of the best infrared images of Jupiter ever taken from Earth.They have been combined with other pictures of the planet, taken from space using technology such as the Hubble Space Telescope, to show that the lightning strikes and storms that create them on Jupiter are formed over huge clouds of water ice and liquid.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThey also show that the dark spots seen in the planet's famous Great Red Spot are actually holes within the cloud cover, rather than changes in the colour of the clouds themselves.The images together represent the result of three years of observations that could be combined using special techniques. Together they are expected to help contribute towards observations from telescopes like Hubble and data from the Juno spacecraft to better understand our still mysterious, huge neighbour.NASA images of Jupiter turned into beautiful abstract artworksThe Gemini data were critical because they allowed us to probe deeply into Jupiter's clouds on a regular schedule, said Michael Wong of UC Berkeley.The scientists used a technique called lucky imaging, Wong said, which sees scientists take a vast number of very short exposure images, but filters them so that only the sharpest images taken when Earth's atmosphere is stable are used. That allowed the scientists to create images that rival the view from space, Wong said.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘Good Morning Britain’ presenter has made frequent and controversial&nbspattacks on the former ‘Suits’ star since her relationship with Prince Harry went publicPiers Morgan has admitted his criticisms of Meghan Markle on&nbspGood Morning Britain and from his social media account went “too far”.In an interview with&nbspThe Sunday Times,&nbspthe presenter addressed his controversial outbursts against Markle, along with a number of his other public grievances.Morgan has previously accused Markle and Prince Harry&nbspof showing a “staggering disrespect” to the Queen over their decision to step back as senior royals.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHe branded those&nbspwho claimed that Markle’s treatment in the press and by the public was fuelled by racism as&nbsp“race-baiting pundits who want to be on TV”. He has also dismissed accusations that his own criticisms of Markle were driven by racism and sexism.In 2018, a&nbspDaily Mail&nbspcolumn written by the GMB host attacked the former&nbspSuits&nbspstar as a “social climbing actress” who “landed the role of her life” by becoming involved with the&nbsproyal family.Every film and TV series coming to Netflix UK in MayPiers Morgan tests negative for coronavirusPiers Morgan cleared by Ofcom after 4,000 complaints over interviewsIn January this year, Morgan leaked screenshots of his direct messages&nbspwith Markle on Twitter, leading many to suggest that Morgan’s vendetta was due to Markle ending her contact with him, after her relationship with Prince Harry was made public.During the interview,&nbspjournalist Decca Aitkenhead&nbspinformed the presenter that she felt his vendetta against Markle had made him look “ugly”, and asked whether, in hindsight, he would have “dialled any of it down”.“Yeah, probably,” Morgan responded.&nbsp“I think that’s a perfectly fair criticism. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Police forces and HM coastguard report increase in incidents amid warm weatherA conga line celebration on VE Day was criticised for breaching the lockdown&nbspas&nbspBoris Johnson pleaded with the public to stay at home over the bank holiday weekend.TV footage showed dozens of villagers in Grappenhall near Warrington dancing down the street while holding a rope at two-metre intervals&nbspin an attempt to maintain socially distancing.However viewers and social media users erupted in fury at the video, with the anonymous author known as&nbspThe Secret Barrister describing it as “breathtakingly stupid”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“This appears to amount to a clear breach of the regulations,” he said. “Unless anybody has any suggestions as to how “Performing the conga” might be said to amount to a reasonable excuse for leaving the house ... we are a nation of idiots”It was just one of a series of incidents which appeared to conflict with the government’s coronavirus guidance amid rising concern over an increase in the number of people&nbspflouting of the lockdown across the UK.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastThey included complaints that a group of up to 100 people had gathered in Salford Quays in Manchester to drink and spray champagne before being dispersed by police on Friday afternoon.Live BBC coverage of a VE Day party in the Portsmouth suburb&nbspof Cosham also appeared to show a large gathering in the&nbspstreet ⁠— although the presenter attempted to reassure viewers that they were social distancing and that&nbsp“perspectives on camera can sometimes be deceiving”. ​Meanwhile Humberside Police said that “lots of people” were holding large gatherings on Friday in defiance of social distancing guidelines. “We will continue to enforce and and fine if appropriate,” the force added.Police also reported stopping and turning away cars travelling long distances for short holidays or to visit the beach.In Cumbria, police stopped a family of four on the M6 as they drove from London to Motherwell for a three-day holiday. title: hundreds of thousands of benefit claimants waiting for assessments as dwp staff diverted due to
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Families say lack of clarity&nbspover visa policy during pandemic leaving them in state of limboThousands of people in the UK could&nbspbe forced to leave the country within weeks because their visas are set to expire before the end of May.The Home Office said on 24 March that anyone&nbspwhose leave had expired or was due to expire between 24 January and 31 May, and who could not leave the UK because of Covid-19, would have their visas extended to the end of May. There has since been no update on this guidance.Immigration lawyers accused the department of leaving people in a “stressful and precarious” situation by maintaining that the visa extensions would only last&nbspuntil the end of this month, and called on ministers to urgently&nbspextend the date to September.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesVisa holders who did not qualify for the extension but whose visas are due to expire soon after 31 May are also worried because lockdown has meant they are unable to apply to extend their leave due to the closure of English&nbsplanguage test centres and the inability to make&nbspapplications that need to be submitted from outside&nbspthe UK.Ben Hicks, 36, said his family had been left in limbo because they have been unable to get clarity on&nbspwhether his Chinese wife, Tingting Zhang, 36, who flew from&nbspWuhan on an evacuation flight in February to be with him&nbspand their five-year-old daughter Sufei, would be able to stay in Britain.Ms Zhang, who was granted a six-month visa&nbspon arriving in the UK, had been planning to submit a spouse application before the pandemic started so that she could live with her husband and daughter permanently, but because it is an out-of-country&nbspapplication ⁠–&nbspmeaning it has to be submitted from outside the UK ⁠–&nbspshe is now not able to do so.The Home Office has said that people whose visas expire before the end of May can apply for out-of-country visas&nbspfrom inside Britain, but Ms Zhang’s&nbspvisit visa ends in August so she does not qualify.Mr Hicks, who met his wife 12 years ago while they were both working on a cruise ship, said he was being “sent round in circles” when he tried to phone the Home Office to clarify what they should do, and that the situation was putting the family’s life on hold for even longer.Home Office criticised over ‘lack of clarity’ on NHS visa extensionsMigrants told to rely on ‘investments and savings’ during lockdownHome Office urged to grant NHS visa extensions to care workers The couple already faced a setback in starting a life together when the Home Office refused Ms Zhang’s fiancee visa in 2014 on the basis that Mr Hicks was not working in the UK, due to working on a cruise ship. Since then, they have spent long periods apart while he has looked for a new job&nbspin order to meet the minimum income requirement for a spouse visa.“I’ve been working hard for nine months to get this sorted. We just want to get on with it so we can finally start a life together as a family. If it wasn’t for the pandemic we would have applied by now and she would probably be here long-term. But at this point, unless the Home Office revises the guidance, she will have to leave again&nbspin August,” he said.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The Home Office has failed to provide a concession or any sort of clear guidance for people in this situation.“If they apply without a test they run the risk of refusal or even having their route changed from five years to 10 years. If refused, they potentially face a financial loss of around £2,000 to £3,000, the risk of becoming overstayers and hence ‘illegal’ and will no doubt lose their jobs and possibly also face removal action and hence be potentially split up from their families.”Mr Bhangal warned that a Windrush-style issue could emerge, adding: “The Home Office tends to wait for a problem or scandal to occur and then try to solve it as opposed to try and prevent foreseeable problems in the first place.“We have seen this with the recent Windrush scandal, which could have been prevented if the Home Office had been proactive and more willing to just talk to the victims before issuing removal and deportation notices. title: coronavirus public transport social distancing shapps
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Transport secretary also outlines £2bn package for cycling and walking projects to address ‘enormous logistical challenge’Grant Shapps has revealed that large swathes of the country’s public transport network will be reduced to just 10&nbspper cent capacity due to&nbspcoronavirus&nbspsocial distancing measures –&nbspeven when full services resume.The transport secretary said getting Britain moving again while&nbspavoiding overcrowding represented&nbspan “enormous logistical challenge”, and even with every train, bus&nbspand tram fully operational it “will not be enough”.He also warned that moving beyond coronavirus will be a “gradual” process, rather than a “single leap to freedom”, as Boris Johnson prepares to address the nation on Sunday evening, setting out the country’s next phase in the pandemic that has claimed more than&nbsp31,000 lives in the UK.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Shapps said the prime minister will proceed with “extreme caution” in easing the lockdown&nbspbut hinted some restrictions could be tightened, such as the mandatory self-isolation for 14 days of&nbsppeople arriving in Britain.On the scale of the challenge facing the country’s transport system, he said: “When we do emerge, the world will seem quite different, or at least for some time. The need to maintain social distancing means that our public transport system cannot go back to where it left off.Created with Sketch.How coronavirus lockdowns changed the world's most polluted cities Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.“Here is a very stark fact: even with public transport reverting to a full service, once you take into account the two-metre social distancing rule, there will only be effective capacity for one in 10&nbsppassengers in many parts of the network. Just a tenth of the old capacity.”Speaking at the No 10 daily press conference, he also said £2bn of a £5bn fund announced earlier this year&nbspwill be used to “put cycling and walking at the heart of our transport policy”, with a national cycling plan to be published in early June.Of this money, £250m&nbspwill be used for “swift, emergency” measures to make cycling and walking safer, with pop-up bike lanes, wider pavements and cycle and bus-only streets created in England.Mr Shapps, however, said the changes represented a “health opportunity”, adding that millions of people had taken up cycling and walking during the lockdown, with some areas experiencing a 70 per cent rise in the number of people on bikes for exercise or travel.“For employees who want to start to cycle to work&nbspbut don’t have a bike right now, the popular cycle-to-work scheme already allows workers to save between 25 and 39 per cent on the cost of a new bike, or indeed electric bike,” he added.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailThe Department for Transport&nbsphas said&nbspvouchers will be issued for cycle repairs in an effort to encourage people to “get their old bikes out of the shed”. E-scooter trials will also be fast-tracked by ministers – from next year to next month.Mr Shapps said: “This £2bn announcement represents the most significant package of cycling, walking and green travel by any British government.”The announcement comes as campaigners called for a fundamental redesign of the transport system to help prevent a bounce-back in air pollution once the lockdown is eventually lifted by the government.In a letter to Mr Shapps and the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, nine organisations, including Greenpeace UK and Transport Action Network, said it would be “completely absurd&nbspif, after the unprecedented efforts and sacrifices made to save thousands of lives from Covid-19, we allowed thousands more to be cut short by the devastating impacts of toxic pollution”.A YouGov poll commissioned by Greenpeace also found that 71 per cent of the public were concerned about the possibility of air pollution returning to pre-lockdown levels once the stringent restrictions are lifted.The survey also suggested&nbsp58 per cent backed the introduction of cycle lanes on urban main roads, along with increased government funding for walking and cycling infrastructure.Department for Transport&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Vice president's campaign staff accuses Jimmy Kimmel of selectively editing clip&nbspLate-night host Jimmy Kimmel&nbsphas apologised to&nbspMike Pence for&nbspa segment on his show that implied he delivered&nbspempty boxes of protective medical equipment&nbspto&nbspa nursing home, but criticised the vice president for a staged publicity stunt.&nbspThe controversy arose following a visit by&nbspMr Pence to the Woodbine Rehabilitation and Healthcare Centre in Alexandria, Virginia, to deliver protective medical equipment on behalf of the US Federal Emergency Management Agency.&nbspAfter being filmed&nbspunloading several boxes of protective gear from a van, the vice president is told by a staff member that&nbspthe&nbsprest of the boxes in the vehicle were empty.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Pence&nbspresponded: Well can I carry the empty ones, just for the camera? The vice president appeared to be joking, and did not actually deliver any empty boxes.&nbspPPEBut the clip was picked up by Mr Kimmel&nbspin a segment on his show.Mike Pence pretending to carry empty boxes of&nbspPPE&nbspinto a hospital is the perfect metaphor for who he is, and what he's doing. A big box of nothing, delivering another box of nothing, Mr&nbspKimmel&nbspsaid.Mr Kimmel was accused by a member of Mr Pence's campaign staff of selectively editing the clip used on his show.This is absolute garbage spread by @JimmyKimmel, tweeted Jon Thompson, Mr Pence's campaign communications director. Pence is clearly joking about empty boxes &amp if Kimmel showed the full clip from CSPAN, not the one he selectively edited, you see and hear it.Mr Kimmel later issued something of an&nbspapology&nbspon Twitter.It would appear that @vp was joking about carrying empty boxes for a staged publicity stunt. The full video reveals that he was carrying full boxes for a staged publicity stunt. My apologies. I know how dearly this administration values truth, he wrote.The Trump administration has faced criticism for its response to the coronavirus pandemic. In the early months of the outbreak, medical staff on the frontlines of treating the disease faced severe shortages of&nbspprotective equipment.On Thursday, Donald Trump&nbspcontradicted a nurse who said that supply of personal protective equipment, or PPE, has been sporadic across the US and&nbspinside the community health centre where she works.Tracking the coronavirus outbreak around the world in maps and chartsWhen can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsListen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastSophia Thomas, president of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, told the president that she has reused her&nbspN95&nbspmask “for a few weeks” before bringing a new one to the White House, which hosted the president’s signing of a&nbspproclamation recognising National Nurses Day&nbspduring the&nbspcoronavirus&nbsppandemic. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Stop the Wildlife Trade exclusive: Ending fur farming&nbspwould substantially reduce the risk of another pandemic, letter to President Xi Jinping saysChina is considering moves that would entrench its vast fur industry further into the country’s economy, raising worries over the spread of coronavirus among animals crowded together in small spaces.The country’s agriculture ministry is proposing to reclassify mink, raccoon dogs, silver foxes and blue foxes as domestic livestock, rather than wild animals, which they are now.Animal-welfare lobbyists say the change is to protect the industry from the global pressure to end the farming of wild species because of the coronavirus pandemic.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesChina breeds and kills more than 50 million animals on fur farms a year, according to Humane Society International, which has written to President Xi Jinping objecting to the plan during its consultation phase.The industry was worth 389 billion yuan (about £48bn) in 2016, according to a Chinese study.Created with Sketch.The reality of fur farming: in pictures Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A fox at a fur farm in Pushkino, RussiaBlack and silver mink kits in a small cage at a fur farm in British Columbia, Canada, 2014A black mink chewing at the bars of their cage at a fur farm in British Columbia, Canada, 2014Mink kits lying atop a dead mink in a nesting box at a fur farm in Sweden, 2010Mink crammed into a filthy cage at a fur farm in Quebec, Canada, 2014Injured mink kits at a fur farm in Sweden, 2010No leg.
