title: sun readers salute britains bravest army tradesmen st john ambulance
story: Our Hail Your Heroes paper pullout, now in its seventh week, is the place where YOU have shone a light on the good deeds that are getting us through these dark times.Today we reveal a volunteer who spent his st birthday helping others – and military veterans beating PTSD by giving their all.Thanks to each of you named here. You are all amazing.If you want your message to be published FREE in The Sun on Sunday email sundayfeatures@the-sunWe’re proud of every one of you!I WOULD like to thank our amazing colleagues at CO-OP for going above and beyond to ensure communities continue to be supported, and to thank our members and customers for working with us during this uncertain time.Debbie Robinson, Chief Executive, Central England Co-op.I FEEL the BRITISH ARMY are unsung heroes of the fight against Covid-.Like the rest of the nation, I have unlimited respect for the NHS and the thousands of carers and essential workers who are doing amazing work to fight this terrible virus with selfless commitment. Every Thursday I go outside with the rest of the country to applaud.But the Army is left out of the heartfelt thanks that we, rightly, hear for other essential workers. The Army is working tirelessly, testing hundreds of thousands potential Covid- sufferers, with minimal PPE. Soldiers are working long hours, often having to self-isolate away from family.Joanne DaviesBURTON-ON-TRENT SCRUBBERS have been doing a fantastic job making scrubs for NHS staff in the local area.TINA ELLISON GRIST and a TEAM OF SEAMSTRESSES have been busy producing gowns. BILLY CLIFFE, alias Billy Fish, has been dressing up and running a home auction to raise money for the materials – more than £, has been raised to date. Tina and Billy are real heroes.DerekClfeWE would like to thank our son MARTIN HILTON, from Herne Bay, Kent, for doing all our shopping and keeping us both safe during the lockdown. Both he and his we are essential workers and we are very proud of them.Mum and DadTHANKS to all BOOTS STAFF for going to work during this pandemic, and especially to the Ryde High Street branch on the Isle of Wight. It’s been so manic, so physically and mentally draining.Pam GrovesWE would like to say a heartfelt thank you to our beautul daughter LISA WILSON, who works her -hour shts or longer every week in a private nursing home in Cardf. Lisa is a psychiatric nurse and knows the risks of her job but just shrugs her shoulders and says she is doing her bit like all the other frontline workers. As well as this, Lisa looks after her daughter, Jordane, and lives with her fiance Paul. Every Thursday we clap, while worrying for our own heroine Lisa.Rob and Janette WilsonFor kind-hearted chef Andrew spent it volunteering at Southend Hospital after he was put on furlough.But he says it was a birthday to remember as he has “the best volunteering job” overseeing a “kindness table” of donated food items.Every day generous people and businesses donate to it as a way of saying thanks to NHS staff – and Andrew and a team of volunteers are there to receive everything from chocolate to toiletries to distribute to heroic staff on the front line. Last week his kindness was also ed when staff brought him a surprise st birthday cake.Andrew, from Shoebury, Essex, says: “I was happy to volunteer on my st birthday as it’s such an amazing role.“I couldn’t believe it when I was presented with a cake. I was almost in tears when I saw they’d gone the extra mile for me.“ I absolutely love volunteering at the hospital, the people are just brilliant. It’s one of the best things I’ve ever done.“I see extraordinary kindness every day, from the staff helping people to those wanting to give something back to them.”Andrew began volunteering for the hospital last month after being furloughed from his job as a chef at the Stop the World café in Leigh.He says: “The hospital had put an ad out for volunteers. I applied straight away. I wasn’t scared at all about working in a hospital during the crisis. I was just keen to help.”As well as manning the “kindness table” Andrew has also been driving to collect donations. Hardworking NHS staff are able to choose items, like cakes and chocolate, during their much-needed breaks.He says: “It’s the small things that brighten up their day and I’m glad I’m able to be part of this.”This is not Andrew’s first time volunteering. He also works as a first-aider for St John Ambulance in his spare time.Andrew is so dedicated to helping others that he also missed out on his th birthday celebrations while helping St John Ambulance at the London Marathon. He says: “ I love helping others and get so much out of volunteering. When I get back to work I’m still hoping I can help out at the hospital, as it’s been such a great and fulfilling experience.”Voluntary services manager Jane O’Connell said: “Andrew has been a godsend. He is always available and always so cheerful.“Due to age, heath issues and lockdown, we had to do without  of our  volunteers last month.“We’ve been overwhelmed by the level of support and can’t thank all of them enough, including Andrew.”HUGS and kisses to SAMANTHA CONWAY and NICOLE PARKER and all the staff at THE EVERGREENS CARE HOME, Talbot Woods, Bournemouth, who do a fantastic job looking after the residents. Take lots of care and keep safe.Harry  DarcyI WOULD like to thank ZACH ALMOND, who is a paramedic and has not only been saving lives around the country and working so hard for the NHS, he has also been so kind posting on Facebook and offering to get groceries for the vulnerable anywhere in North London. He doesn’t rest. He is such a kind and caring friend.Jemma PrittieHOW about a big mention for our COMMUNITY CARERS visiting clients in their own homes. They are putting themselves on the frontline by being out and about every day. Well done and thank you.Jan WoodbridgePLEASE give a big shout-out to our decades-old friend CARER JULIE BRYANT, who is a carer in Plympton, Devon, and doing an amazing job with her colleagues. They are unsung heroes.Lizzie and Sarah I KNOW there are numerous people who deserve praise with regard to the Covid- battle, but there are two doctors who are on TV doing a grand job spelling out easy-to-understand advice. These doctors are Channel ’s DR SARAH JARVIS and ITV’s and The Sun’s DR HILARY JONES. Thanks so much to both of them, for all their invaluable help.N. Newton, RomfordON March , after helping an elderly gentleman who was struggling to find things he needed in the supermarket, SPALDING COVID KINDNESS TEAM was set up. There are now  committee members and around  volunteers. On Tuesday,  bulk fruit boxes went to care homes, schools and frontline workers,  care packages went out on Wednesday,  fresh fruit-and-veg bags were packed and  inidual requests for prescriptions and essential shopping were sorted on Thursday.The team deal with calls for emotional support and help people stay connected with distant relatives. They have taken a card and sung Happy Birthday to a -year-old lady whose family couldn’t visit her. And they are VOLUNTEERS, who give so much help to the vulnerable in Spalding and the surrounding area. So thank you.Bob WishartBORIS JOHNSON is back running the country and again lting the spirits of the people of the UK. Well done to Boris, and his MINISTERS AND EXPERTS, for all the hard work they have done and continue to do. Thank you.Cheryl LloydBilly MacLeod and his volunteers from Veterans In Action are collecting and distributing food across Hampshire — and demand is skyrocketing.Billy, , served as a corporal in the Royal Engineers until  and completed tours in Northern Ireland, Belize and Germany before suffering from PTSD.He said: “Until last week we had delivered more than , packages of essentials but this week the number of people we’re helping has doubled.“The deeper we get into this, the more the need is rising. We collected food generously donated for an extra , people last week. It went to everyone from the elderly self-isolating to school kids to ensure they get a decent meal inside them.“Every one of our team has mental-health issues as a result of their service. They are helping themselves by helping others. And we are all proud to do our bit to help Britain again.”The Hampshire charity normally organises foreign expeditions to help veterans with mental-health problems stay active. Billy said: “As soon as we knew coronavirus would cancel all our planned trips, I knew we could make a dference with our military backgrounds.“Every morning we head out to pick up the bags of food and household items donated by the public, then go through our list of requests. The mountain of goods donated every day makes your heart melt. It gives our volunteer veterans a sense of purpose while helping the community when they need us most. It’s win-win.”Each of the care packages is specically filled with items each family has requested, eventhey have dietary needs such as a nut allergy, or they are vegans.Bags typically contain a range of canned and dried foods, bathroom essentials such as deodorant, wipes and shampoo, and kitchen essentials such as cooking sauces. The team works with the local council and the Andover Isolation Help Group adds in a range of fresh fruit and veg.Keith Tucker has been volunteering with Veterans In Action since .He served in the   Lancers and left as a corporal in the early Eighties suffering from PTSD.“Going out and doing the collections has given me the focus to leave the past where it belongs — in the past. The VIA team is proud to help.”To mark VE Day, the team — which also includes Stephen Reilly, Duncan Crockett and Maurice Sweeney — gave out  care packages in the morning and another  in the afternoon.Billy added: “We’d planned a drive to Berlin to retrace the British Army’s steps in the lead-up to VE Day but the disappointmentvanished the moment we found this new calling.“When you see the look on the faces of these isolated people opening their doors to see a pile of bags filled with essential items, it really gives you perspective.“It’s an honour to be helping out in times like these.”We are so proud of our mammy, daughter and sister CARRIEANN CHAPPELL. She goes into work everyday as a creche worker to look after the children of other key workers, enabling them to stay on the frontline. She always keeps a massive smile on her face and makes sure everyone stays safe. She does all of this while homeschooling her own children and looking after other vulnerable family members and neighbours. We honestly couldn’t be prouder of you, keep up the good work!The Chappell ClanI WOULD like to thank KOPI KALANATHAN, a COSTCUTTER store owner who has gone the extra mile. Kopi and his team worked around the clock to bring forward the opening of his new shop because he knew local people were crying out for access to essential items during these challenging times. They are offering free deliveries for the vulnerable and NHS workers, as well as offering nurses, ambulance staff and police officers free coffee, breakfast and lunch. Kopi is also reserving essential stock for nursing homes.SophieMANY thanks to my husband KEVIN DAVIS for his constant help and perseverance. He works nights as an HGV driver delivering to supermarkets, and does all our shopping, including for my mum, who is  today and lives with us. I have diabetes so am on lockdown. Kevin also makes time to work on the garden and helps keep the housework under control. Love you lots.Julie DavisTHANKS to my husband PATRICK JONES, who moved from London to Northern Ireland with me to support my ageing parents John and Maeve. His support for my father, especially, has been amazing and during lockdown his kindness and sense of humour keep Dad’s spirits up. He also motivates Dad to stay mobile, which is key.Marie JonesA HUGE well done and thank you to Health Minister MATT HANCOCK and all the team involved in getting our testing capacity and delivery to the k daily target. I’m delighted that they’ve been able to show just how much can be done to help save lives. A huge well done, again.Mike ScottA No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.A BIG thank you to my son-in-law SIMON O’SHEA, my daughter CATHY O’SHEA and GRANDDAUGHTERS for their loving care and kindness, in these dficult times. They have kept me safe, well-fed and sane. In these sad, dark days of stre, they light up my le. Thank you, too, to the many people who are helping the over-s, vulnerable and lonely in lockdown and care homes. Thank you, NHS angels, for your care. You are my heroes. God bless you all.Patricia BeechAFTER Covid- is over and we get back to normal, my heroes will always be NHS staff. The days when my heroes were my football team, certain golfers including Ryder Cup winners, pop stars, world champs in whatever field . . . those days have gone for good. British Hollywood stars, international pop superstars, the odd politician . . .  well, they’re history. I will never hold them in the same respect and awe as ALL NHS STAFF from DOCTORS, CLEANERS and NURSES, even backroom ADMINISTRATION STAFF all risking their lives to save thousands, day in day out. Thank you, all NHS staff, whatever you do. You are amazing.Richard FarrarPOSTMEN AND POSTWOMEN are an important and valuable part of society. For older members of society who do not see people regularly it is a god-send. Keep up the good work girls and boys, and keep the country smiling.Robert WestFROM helping ambulance staff to supporting emergency staff around the country, to training colleagues in Covid- treatment skills, our ST JOHN AMBULANCE VOLUNTEERS have the public’s safety at heart and are proud to support the NHS. Your combined passion and commitment are exemplary and we thank you for everything you are doing.St John Ambulance ServiceI NOMINATE my local ALDI WAKEFIELD. They seem to be the only supermarkets who are looking after their customers by sanitising every trolley at the point of entry to the store and doing the same when it is ed. They are clearly more aware than the other brand leaders of the importance of infection control in these dficult times.Eileen BaileyWE quite rightly applaud our front-line staff in hospitals and public transport, but please let’s not forget the faceless anonymous guys who keep our UTILITY SERVICES flowing. Without electricity, gas and water we would be in real trouble. Thank you to all the employees working so hard.Brian GodfreyI’D like to nominate LUCY LOXLEY from Stocksbridge, South Yorks. She has a young family including a baby and yet has taken the time to start a supportive Facebook page, Steel City Lockdown. She shares her ups and downs, has organised bulk buys from a wholesaler and shared it with others. I answered the door to discover a parcel of blackberry gin and tonic and Lucy was getting back into her car. I didn’t know her before this but I now count her as a friend. And the gin was very enjoyable too!Fay HowardI DON’T know how we’d manage without my daughter SHARON FOTHERGILL, my son CHRISTOPHER TANDY and granddaughter AMY TRICKETT for keeping us supplied with our shopping and cooked meals. And our great pals NEIL AND MOLLY FOX for keeping us supplied with reading material and chocolate!David Tandy, , and we Barbara, , of WakefieldI’D like to say thanks to LEEDS IRISH CENTRE. It should have been enjoying massive celebrations for its th anniversary this summer, with a book out and a number of events and parties. Instead, twice a week, the staff make over  sandwiches which are then shared via the city charity, Simon On The Streets, to local homeless people. The centre has a long record for helping those in need and continues its kindness during this crisis. They are unsung heroes.Julie Moore, LeedsTHANKS to EMMA ETHERINGTON, a registered general nurse who has had extra training to work in ICU. She’s worked constantly over these past few weeks while her husband looks after their two boys at home. She has had over  years’ experience as a nurse and it shows with how amazing she is in handling it all! Such a brave lady who goes above and beyond for anyone. She is  per cent in the right job!Paige Louise BakerAbigail Oleck-Hewett, , whose clients include Lady Gaga and Holly Willoughby, had to close her skin business BeauSkin London and tanning firm Beaubronz when the lockdown hit.So she signed up to five volunteer organisations and donated all the PPE from her salons to hospitals.Abi, of Dorking, Surrey, says: “There is no way I was going to sit at home and do nothing – I want to help my community. It’s a full-time job. I’m so busy that I need a diary to schedule it all in.“But I realised early on there was an urgent need to support the most vulnerable. My mum Vivienne is  and my grandmother Margaret is  and they live on the same street – and I was taking deliveries from Surrey to Kent to them.“I knew there were thousands of others out there who also need support and help. With my training in infection-control, I was confident I could not only deliver what they need, but also do it with the minimum risk to them.”Abi, who is also a guest presenter on QVC and Ideal World, adds: “It may be dferent from my day job, but it is no less rewarding.“What really brought home the seriousness is that we do a weekly delivery of  food bags in a tiny village of just , people.“I was shocked so many people were self-isolating or shielding – but this is the effect of Covid-.”I’D like to thank my daughter SAMANTHA ELLIS. She’s helping on the call centre for Covid-, helping and directing people for testing. She works for Hays Travel and was put on furlough. The company has worked with the Government to get their staff to work from home, helping with the call centre. At least she and her colleagues can do something to help and not just sit back.Anne EllisI’M so proud of my son SHAUN COSTELLO, who drives lorries for Morrisons supermarket, delivering food to the country, and my granddaughters, mum-of-three DANIELLE LAWS, who also works for the supermarket and is always checking on me, and ALEX COSTELLO, a single mum who has swapped working as a cleaner at the local Pinderfields Hospital to train as an emergency care assistant.Madge CostelloTHANKS to the homeless charity SPEAR LONDON, working tirelessly to feed and shelter the homeless in south-west London. The staff are another face of frontline workers, helping the vulnerable despite the intense dficulties and dangers the pandemic presents.Ilona HitelWE’D like to thank EMMA GREGORY for having the brave and great idea to open up an environmentally friendly shop in our area. Refill It was to open in June but Emma has worked her socks off to get it open next week. Shoppers are invited to bring their own containers to fill up a range of products including pasta, beans and pulses. She’s determined to buy locally and deserves every success.Elizabeth Drury and Sally SuccoiaWE want to thank our PAPER BOY, MILKMAN and POSTIES, the DELIVERY PEOPLE, BIN MEN, POST OFFICE and CORNER SHOP STAFF and all those with smiles and good wishes. X x xBob and Patsy ChapmanDONCASTER COUNCIL may not be the place you’d expect to find funny, entertaining social media content but it is brilliant and has given me a few laughs while working from home, as well as good advice.The council’s coronavirus history lessons – in brilliant threads with witty gs – is a great example. It’s the little things that lt your day at the moment and whoever is responsible for the council’s Twitter feed is doing a brilliant job! Thank you.Amanda Holmes, Sheffield THANKS to my fitness instructor VICTORIA HUTTON, who runs V Fit in our community. She jumped into action and set up daily virtual fitness classes for us. People are saying it is keeping them sane and another parent said it was the first time their son had done exercise in a month.Maria BoyleTHANKS to JAMIE THRASIVOULOU who has written a poem thanking key workers for their efforts during the coronavirus pandemic. Called This One’s For The Key Workers, it praises “the real heroes keeping this country running” and says they are “the roses to this virus’s thorns”.Blake FallowsWELL done to an amazing bunch of volunteers who call themselves THE HARROGATE SCRUBBERS. Maths teacher FRAN TAYLOR launched the scheme a month ago in response to the PPE challenges faced by the NHS. The now -strong group has raised over £, to make and deliver nearly  scrubs to Harrogate District Hospital.Many local companies are donating materials to support the volunteers who are daily making scrubs. From retired people on their own who say it’s given them a purpose in isolation, to the young who just want to volunteer, the scheme has got the community pulling together. Well done to you all.Christine GreggLUCY FROST, who has a severely disabled son, went into self-imposed lockdown before it was made official, yet she still managed to set up the Tunbridge Wells Self-Isolation Support Group to help local people who are self-isolating. It now has nearly , members. I’d like to give thanks to her.Alice PatienceLEEDS HOMELESS STREET ANGELS are going into hotels and hostels and feeding those they normally help on the streets. They are helping people released early from prison to bed and breakfast places who were living on fast food and are now getting meals and support twice a day.They also do food parcels for scores of vulnerable people. They should be recognised.ALL mums are amazing but I think mine, LINDA SLACK, is extra special. She cleans at a local junior school, being protected by little more than a pair of rubber gloves and a bottle of hand sanitiser, then goes home to take care of my dad, Andy, who has COPD. Mum also checks on her elderly neighbours and her own mum, Margaret Clarke, , to make sure they have everything they need to survive lockdown. She baked me a cake on my birthday and I’d like to say a huge THANK YOU for everything she does.Kerry GanlyClare founded Mid Surrey Community Fridges with pal Tony White two years ago after seeing an item about food waste on Channel ’s Jamie And Jimmy’s Friday Night Feast.They started with a single fridge from which vulnerable people could pick up donated food for free.Now they deliver supplies to those in need – and the pandemic has seen a surge in demand. Last week they delivered , bags of donated food.Clare said: “We set up a community fridge to make unwanted food available for anyone that would like it, at no cost. When we opened, we literally had one fridge.“Since Covid-, demand has gone through the roof. My volunteers have been working -hour days, seven days a week.“We had to close the community fridges for safety reasons but quickly adapted to become a delivery service. At Christmas we had  volunteers. It’s now . A lot of these people have been furloughed, laid off or work part-time and want to do help. Every one of them is incredible.“Before Covid, we were processing kg of donated food a week. Last week it was ,kg. It’s the double low-income families and those on zero-hour contracts who need most help.”Clare fears the next six months will be even tougher for people as the full financial sting is felt.She added: “We’re just at the beginning of this. People from all walks of le will need our help.”PHOTOGRAPHER GILES DULEY is a triple amputee after stepping on an IED while working in Afghanistan. Though he runs a global charity supporting civilians affected by conflict, Giles is now helping his home town of Hastings. He has fund-raised to buy PPE and collected donations of hand cream and lip balms for East Sussex NHS staff. For Giles, it is never about him but his efforts should be recognised.Karen KayWELL done to my friend SUE KELLY. Her daughter, Lily, was worried that as she left her primary school, Pownall Hall School in Wilmslow, Cheshire, her year group would not have any special memories to take with them. They created a video to show that they are still connected even when apart and to spread a little happiness. The children’s personalities shine through and it’s so uplting to watch Pass The Pen. My company, Applehead Media, helped make the film and a special memory for them.Nicola SandsTHANKS to my husband JAMES, a web designer, who has turned his D printer into a one-person le-saving machine, printing over  masks and donating them to NHS staff, GPs, pharmacies, hospices and prison workers in our area.He has been running the printer day and night and delivering the visors too. He has been doing this alongside his full-time job and home-schooling our sons, aged six and three.Anna AlexanderTHANKS to former beauty editor LAUREN EZEKIEL, founder of We C U , who called on old colleagues after learning that healthcare workers’ skin was so dry from sweating under their PPE. She has collected £, of products. Her family help to pack goody bags and local drivers drop them off. I am proud of her.Farzana AliIN one month MANDY GUEST of FOOD  HEROES in Yorkshire has organised , meals for NHS staff at  hospitals using chefs whose businesses are closed. Thank you to her.Chris Sutclfe, HalaxWELL done to ST GILES SCHOOL, Derby’s only special primary, where my daughter, Layla, attends. Staff have made a video supporting families staying home. It used Makaton, a programme using signs and symbols to develop speech, to perform its version of Lean On Me.David MartinsTHANKS to EMMA WHITE, a carer with M Care. She shows amazing care for my granny Maeve, , who is in the last stage of dementia, and support for grandad John, . Her kindness, gentleness and positive attitude has helped our family so much. She’s a ray of sunshine amid the gloom of Covid- and what is yet to come for us.Tess JonesWELL done KATE BLAKEMORE at Motherwell Cheshire, for making sure that expectant women are getting the emotional support they need during lockdown. Her Crewe-based charity has started a helpline offering isolated and expectant mums a dedicated befriender. It’s proving a leline to those on their own during one of the momentous events in their lives.Louise WatersTHANK you to BEN FRANCO and his friend ROCKY, who have ensured vulnerable and elderly people in our village have a hot meal provided for them. Ben runs a small restaurant in our village, which he had to close down, and lost all his income in the process. He decided to open up his kitchen to provide free hot meals for local people in need.Every Friday is now known as Franco’s Friday in the village. Ben makes  meals each week which he delivers to Rocky at Rowley’s Newsagents in the main street.For those who can’t get to the shop, or don’t have people who can collect the meal for them, Ben drives to their homes and leaves food parcels on the doorstep.People like Ben and Rocky are the backbone of communities like ours and they’ve brought the village together in a time when being neighbourly has never been more important.John RoberstonTHANKS to THE YORKSHIRE SOAP COMPANY which has donated thousands of products including soapy Easter rabbits, shower gels and hand creams to Yorkshire hospitals and to local nursing staff. These were gratefully received by all the staff especially after finishing a sht in full PPE on ICU.They are kind people who given so much at a time when when they have had to close stores.Christina KnightTHANK you to staff at TREETOPS HOSPICE CARE, Risley, who are no longer preparing meals on site for patients, so they’ve turned the kitchen into a cake-making enterprise, producing tasty home-made treats every day. A Cake and Care delivery team of staff and volunteers then distribute these along with messages of support, craft activities, puzzles and other useful resources.They are amazing!Katharine LightbrownTHANKS to ANITA AND GARY KNIGHT from Askam-In-Furness, Cumbria. Gary, a railway signal worker, owns seven D printers and has borrowed a further two. He has them running  hours a day to make protective visors and mask extenders for local frontline workers.Retired Anita, , is not in the least technically minded but has been helping day and night to keep production going from their garage and dining room. So far, they’ve made nearly , pieces of equipment for local community care workers.I couldn’t be more proud of them and know those who have benefited are very grateful.Michelle RawlinsTHANK you to telecoms engineer DEAN ANDREWS who works for Airband Community Internet, a rural broadband specialist.The other week he dragged m of armoured cable to make sure a rural community did not lose its broadband during this crisis.The company provides free wi for community hubs, such as village halls and pubs, in their network areas.Naomi SnellingI WOULD like to thank you for the free delivery of my daily Sun for  weeks of lockdown. Also a big shout out for our wonderful NEWSPAPER DELIVERY BOYS, GIRLS AND GROWN-UPS.Peter AllenI WANT to thank all the VOLUNTEERS doing amazing things to keep many leline services going.Daniel ArnoldTO all of my colleagues at SNOWDROP HOUSE CARE HOME in Ware, Herts, who doing an amazing job keeping our residents happy and safe during this crazy time. You are all fantastic and I’m proud to say I’m part of the Snowdrop family. We will get through this.Aimee EldridgeTHANKS to all the brave COMMUNITY HEALTH STAFF and CARERS continuing to go into homes to look after the sick and vulnerable.Clare SweeneyI WANT to thank my PAPER BOY – come wind, rain or shine, he’s been delivering my newspaper with a smile, which is so important.David JacksonI WANT to thank the NURSES who have been working so hard to keep everyone safe. I’ve got friends in the NHS and they don’t earn enough – I hope they get a pay rise when this is all over.Alice MilesTHANK you to our nine-week-old son CARTER ROCCO, born at the start of this pandemic, and to the MIDWIVES at his birth.Mum and DadI THINK all the people working in FOOD SHOPS, CORNER SHOPS and SUPERMARKETS have been amazing. They’ve been at massive risk every day but have been still been going in and making sure everyone has all the things they need to buy.Bianca JarmanTHANKS to Britain’s NURSES. This is more than a job. As a community nurse, I feel privileged to be able to maintain care in this current situation, for all the vulnerable we look after. Each and every one of them holds a place in our heart and together we are family. I want to thank them for just being them.Community nurse Jodie BannisterTHANKS to all the NHS HEROES who are helping the country to pull through.Darren Springer TEACHERS deserve a special mention. They’ve been looking after the kids of key workers. Without them, where would be Lee AdamsTHE proper heroes, in my eyes, are the DOCTORS and NURSES. Amazing job.Daniel JinksIN the nursery where I work I’ve been looking after key workers’ children and it has been helping reduce the strain of those on the frontline. It is great to be able to do my bit. But without KEY WORKERS we wouldn’t be able to get through the pandemic. They are all amazing. Thank you.Bridie SheehanAS a nurse, I want to thank the HOSPITAL PORTERS. These guys are unsung heroes of the NHS.Sarah ClarkeI WANT to thank the BIN MEN and WOMEN who have been out in all weathers working as usual. With everyone being at home, the amount of waste to deal with has been huge, but they never moan or complain.Ian CoxDON’T forget all the COUNCIL FRONT-LINE CARETAKERS keeping tower blocks clean, tidy and free of rubbish and fire hazards, and keeping the tenants safe while putting themselves at risk.Kevin FreemanTHANK you to all the amazing CARE HOME STAFF looking after some of the most vulnerable people. They all deserve medals.Ashley JonesI WANT to shout out to everyone waiting that bit longer for a parcel to come. Orders have been really busy and some days it’s hard to get round to everyone. People seem to realise we are doing our best and it means a lot.Adam ThomasTO all SHOPWORKERS – everyone is doing a fantastic job and you should be proud of yourselves.Nina DaviesMY team at work have done so well in making sure all our young people still feel valued and supported. Well done to them all.Healthworker Keeley ReanneI WANT to pay tribute to all of the ELECTRICIANS, PLUMBERS and TRADESMEN who have been working through this pandemic. I know loads who are also getting food and supplies for people they are working for, particularly the elderly, and they rarely get a mention.Andrew DavisTHANK you to the PUBLIC for clapping us every Thursday. It’s impossible to put into words what it means for morale in the NHS. Please keep it going.Nurse Paul ClarkeTHANKS to my fellow SHOPKEEPERS. The present situation is something we have never experienced before, it has been a rollercoaster of emotions.But the feedback we have received has been amazing, including letters of thanks for the work that we do feeding communities and keeping community spirit up.My approach to le is quite simple really, I believe there is always more we can do to help, and to be kind – and a simple act of kindness really does go a long way. Thanks to everyone who has been so kind in .Stacey FullicksHATS off to the NHS STAFF. I’ve got colleagues on Covid- wards and they are just fighting the good fight.Claire HorganTHANK you to the PETROL STATION STAFF for staying open as usual and always making sure they have a supply of my favourite snacks. I’ll need to go on a diet after lockdown.Mark DavisIN these challenging times, good NEIGHBOURS and VOLUNTEERS are doing amazing jobs like going to the pharmacy to get medicines for others, going to GPs to get prescriptions, and also getting groceries – sometimes early in the morning and sometimes late in the evening. It makes you feel very proud.Kailash SuriTHANKS to my local pub, the DRUNKEN DRAGON, for all the work the owner BEN and the team have done in the community. It makes things that bit easier.Rebecca AdamsWELL done to KIERON PASKIN, a food-waste-disposal lorry driver. Keep the country moving.Nicola PaskinA HUGE well done to CHRISTINE and ABBEY PILLET who have volunteered and been making lots of scrubs and gowns for the NHS at home.Chris BoothSend in YOUR messages of thanks to anyone from all walks of le, who has gone the extra mile for you during these dficult times - and we will publish them for FREE.Send your name, their name and your message of thanks to sundayfeatures@the-sun and well print them next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeffrey epstein three young women prince andrew new york
story: The women, all in their early twenties, were allegedly told to dress up beautully for the meetings at Epsteins New York mansion and promised a bright career future, powerful connections and money in .Evidence seen by the Mail on Sunday reportedly suggests that at least two of the meetings - and possibly all three - occurred during a visit the Duke of York made to Epsteins home in December .The newspaper reports Andrew allegedly had his feet massaged by a woman while watching Colin Firth star in the movie as his grandfather King George VI.The source claimed: Whenever Epstein watched a movie, he requested girls to give him and his guests a foot massage.I am pretty certain Andrew was given the same treatment. It is unlikely they watched the movie alone and without a massage.Literary agent John Brockman has previously claimed he witnessed the Duke of York receiving a foot massage from two Russian women at Epsteins mansion.Epstein, who killed himself in August while awaiting trial on charges of sex trafficking minors, had only months before the  visit completed a -month stint in jail following a conviction for procuring an underage girl for prostitution.Andrew has always maintained he made the trip only to cut ties with Epstein.The prince has previously been accused of having sex with Epstein victim Virginia Roberts when she was , though has always denied wrongdoing.Discussing the  visit in a widely-criticised BBC interview in November, Andrew said: Now, I went there with the sole purpose of saying to him that because he had been convicted, it was inappropriate for us to be seen together.But the account given by the anonymous insider contradicts that claim.I think that it was Epstein who invited Andrew to NYC, the source said.The girls were going to Epstein’s house specically to meet Andrew, not just Epstein.The source identies one of the three women as model Lana Zakocela, who had worked for Victoria Secret, which is owned by Epsteins financial client, Les Wexner.The source also told the Mail on Sunday that Epstein used the prince to improve his image following his release from jail.I think Andrew was incredibly useful for him as a promotion tool, she said.He had just left jail, and to show a guest of such a level was perfect for his social capital.He was telling everyone that the prince was in the city.Epstein also reportedly spoke about watching  Oscar winner The Kings Speech, whose central character is George VI, Andrews grandfather, with Andrew prior its release in the UK.The insider says that Andrew might have received a foot massage from a woman during the screening.Representatives of Prince Andrew have been approached for comment.Our journalists title: sun on sunday hail your hero
story: THE Sun on Sunday has been applauded for journalism excellence for the Hail Your Hero campaign where you, our readers, say thanks to those who have stepped up during the pandemic.A  of expert judges from Press Gazette – the media industry’s bible - recognised it as one of “the best editorial innovations of the pandemic so far”.The campaign – now in its seventh week – has shone a light on unsung heroes and heroines from care workers, to members of the public making vital PPE from their homes and also volunteers distributing food and medical supplies to those who are self-isolating.Press Gazette said: “The pandemic has inspired some news businesses across the UK and beyond to find new ways of reporting and sharing news with readers and viewers.”The Sun was also recognised for its Who Cares Wins campaign which last week celebrated raising £ million towards care packages, food and vital equipment for brave nurses, doctors and NHS staff on the coronavirus frontline.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen withdraw public duties for months longest absence coronavirus
story: THE Queen is due to withdraw from public duties for MONTHS in what could be the longest absence of her -year reign.Her Majesty, who is , will remain at Windsor Castle indefinitely as the coronavirus crisis continues in the UK.Buckingham Palace will be closed to the public this summer for what is thought to be the first time in almost  years.The Sunday Times reports that her diary of engagements into the autumn is also on hold.She had plans for a state visit to South Africa in October, but it is not yet knownthis will go ahead.Events including Trooping the Colour, the Order of the Garter service and her summer garden parties have already been cancelled, while Royal Ascot - which she attends annually - will only take place behind closed doors,at all.The Queen has recently given two public addresses to the nation.In the first, on April , she echoed WWII forces sweetheart Dame Vera Lynn as she promised those coping with forced separation from loved ones we will meet again.Some million people watched the speech.And on VE Day, she urged Brits: Never give up - never despair.The monarch usually s from Windsor to Buckingham Palace in May before taking her annual summer break at Balmoral in July.However, royal aides say she has no engagements and will not leave Windsor until the threat from coronavirus clears.Her last public engagement was the Commonwealth Service at Westminster Abbey on March .She has been isolating at Windsor with the Duke of Edinburgh since March .Despite that, she has been in regular contact with the prime minister and other world leaders.The news comes on the day Boris Johnson prepares to outline his road map out of lockdown.Yesterday, coronavirus deaths rose to , after  more people lost their lives to the deadly disease.A royal source told The Times: “The Queen won’t do anything which goes against the advice of people in her [age] category and she’s going to take all the appropriate advice.There are discussions about what we could and couldn’t do come October.We haven’t cancelled a load of engagements, but nothing is going into Her Majesty’s diary at the moment.“If there is advice in the coming months that it’s fine for her to come back to London, she may do that, but until that time, she’d want to be seen to be being responsible in her actions for the nation.”

title: different areas lockdown levels
story: DIFFERENT parts of Britain could have tougher lockdown levels to handle the crisis, a minister has warned.Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick today revealed the Government could soon start cracking down on the parts of the nation most affected by the coronavirus pandemic.Appearing on Sky News, Mr Jenrick explained contact tracing could help isolate where people were most at risk.He said: “There will be a centre for biosecurity that will bring this data together, monitor the progress against the virus in all parts of the country and inform our response.If we see there are particular outbreaks in particular neighbourhoods, schools, towns, we may be able to take particular measures in those places.“If there are outbreaks in one particular place we will have the opportunity to increase measures again.The senior minister also backed the new colour-coded alert scheme, ranging from green to red, which will be used to highlight increased risk from the virus.He said: It will be very transparent, people will be able to see at what point we are in controlling the virus.At the moment we believe the country is at four on a scale of five, with five being the most concerning.Our aspiration is to bring that down as swtly as we can to three.Mr Jenrick also defended the Governments new slogan advising Brits to stay alert.He said: We need to have a broader message because we want to slowly and cautiously restart the economy and the country.I understand people are anxious about the future but we want now to have a message which encourages people to go to work.It comes as the Prime Minister is set to warn the UK later today that the country is entering the most dangerous phase of the outbreak.The PM will urge “maximum caution” as he unveils his road map out of lockdown.Mr Johnson told The Sun on Sunday: “This is the dangerous bit.“We’re past the peak now but we’ll have to work even harder to get every step right.On Thursday, the Government met for their obligated three-week review, with Dominic Raab announcing in the daily press briefing that the lockdown has been extended for another three weeks.The Foreign Secretary says there is no change yet as the virus is still deadly and infectious, but some minor tweaks are expected.The PM is expected to make an address to the nation detailing a menu of options on how the nation will exit lockdown restrictions and re-energise the economy while still suppressing the spread of the virus.Some of the measures included will be to encourage those who are able toto work under strict guidelines on social distancing and hygiene.Mr Johnson is also expected to announce plans to re-open more public spaces, as long as members of the public stick to the social distancing guidelines. px,px, px" title: prince charles royal mail letter
story: PRINCE Charles and Camilla have thanked hero postal workers for their dedication, resilience and hard workduring the coronavirus crisis.The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall addressed a letter to Everyone at Royal Mail and ended it with heartfelt thanks - and a big thumbs up.A touching video shows the couple leaving the letter outside their front door at Birkhall, Aberdeenshire, where it was picked up by stunned local postie Neil Martin.The letter reads: Receiving such a personal message at this dficult and anxious time can mean an enormous amount.We feel sure that a very large number of these special greetings will be treasured for years to come. They may even become a valuable resource for social historians in the future.Postmen and postwomen are trusted figures in our local communities. They are a constant presence in an ever-changing world. For some people, they are a point of daily human contact a friendly, familiar face.The couple also said the value of Royal Mail workers has never been more important as many people have taken the time to write a letter, or a card, to those from whom they are separated.And they praised how posties have been forced to overcome personal fears to carry out their jobs in a new way.The royals wrote: Many of you, we know, have gone above and beyond what is normally expected of you.We have heard wonderful stories of postmen and postwomen checking on older and vulnerable residents, raising funds for good causes, even wearing fancy dress costumes to raise a smile...Today, as many people - ourselves included - are obliged to stay at home, Royal Mail plays an absolutely vital role in keeping family and friends in touch with one another. For that, we can only say how deeply grateful we are and send you our kindest wishes.Royal Mail has launched a Thumbs Up For Your Postie campaign to encourage customers to show their appreciation for postal workers.The public has been urged to give posties on their round a thumbs up from a safe m distance.The royals have been paying tribute to unsung heroes during the pandemic.Prince Philip released a rare public statement last month where he recognised the work done by NHS staff along with council workers and binmen.Prince Charles, , himself battled the disease in March and helped virtually open NHS Nightingale in London after recovering.The second in line to the throne has stepped up his royal duties in recent weeks, while the Queen is reportedly due to withdraw from public duties for months.Her Majesty, , will remain at Windsor Castle indefinitely as the coronavirus crisis continues in the UK.Prince Charles and Camilla led the nation in a poignant two minute silence on the th anniversary of VE Day to remember the fallen.The couple each laid a wreath at a war memorial at Balmoral Castle - title: china uses coronavirus control south china sea
story: CHINA is using the coronavirus crisis to assert control of the vital South China Sea and flex its military muscles, it is claimed.The region contains strategic sea lanes and has rich fishing grounds along with trillions of pounds’ worth of oil and gas deposits.Beijing claims it owns most of the disputed patch of ocean, despite several other countries having seemingly legitimate claims under international law.Taiwan, Malaysia, Vietnam, the Philippines and Brunei all claim rights to their own chunks under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.The convention states that nations’ claims to the waters around them must be measured from land.To thwart this, Beijing has been building man-made islands on top of coral reefs in the middle of the South China Sea for years, before using them as military bases – despite promising not to.And China has now been accused of “bullying” and using coronavirus pandemic as a distraction to take over the region completely.The US this week sent two warships – the USS Montgomery and the USNS Cesar Chavez – to the hotspot as part of a “presence operation”.The move came in response to reports Chinese ships were harassing Panamanian-flagged vessel West Capella, which was drilling for oil in an area claimed by Malaysia.It was the second time in a month US warships had to be deployed to deter alleged Chinese harassment of neighbouring countries.The first was just weeks ago when Chinese government survey ship Haiyang Dizhi  stalked another oil exploration vessel operated by Malaysia.Months earlier, the same ship is believed to have conducted a similar operation in the waters off Vietnam.The US State Department said at the time: “China should cease its bullying behaviour and refrain from engaging in this type of provocative and destabilising activity.”And last month, China set up new administrative districts for the disputed islands it lays claim to.It named  islands in the announcement, claiming sovereignty over underwater features along the way.It prompted US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to warn that China “has moved to take advantage of” the coronavirus distraction with its “unilateral announcement of administrative districts over disputed islands and maritime areas in the South China Sea”.The Chinese navy has also deployed more warships to the region in recent weeks.Chinese aircraft carrier Liaoning led a flotilla of five other warships into the Western Pacic through the Miyako Strait to the northeast of Taiwan on April , according to Taiwans Defence Ministry.On April , the Chinese warships exercised in waters east and south of Taiwan, the ministry said.Meanwhile, the US Navy was forced to tie up the aircraft carrier USS Theodore Roosevelt at Guam while it battles to contain a coronavirus outbreak among the crew.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tests flown us lab issues
story: BRITAIN secretly flew , coronavirus tests to the US after issues in the lab.The Department of Health last night admitted tests were being flown to America in their thousands to ensure they get the results as quickly as possible.They have now told The Sundaythe move was among the contingencies to deal with teething problems.It comes with the UK Government failing to hit the hundred thousand daily testing target every day for the past week.Speaking this morning, Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick admitted: “There was an issue with one of the labs and we put in place our contingency plan, which was to take some of the tests to the United States for the tests to be processed.“That was exactly in line with the detailed plans the Department for Health had made in advance.”The Government had previously admitted experiencing problems in a Northern Ireland lab, but made no mention of having to ship tests to America.A Department of Health source said: We were able to send approximately , test samples to a US laboratory earlier this week.Validation of the results will be completed in the UK, and all results will be ed to patients as quickly as possible.They are believed to be being tested at a university laboratory in the south of the US.The department source added: Delays in the system this week arose as a result of operational issues in our lab network.We have worked to resolve these issues and capacity is rapidly being restored.”Pressure has grown on the Health Secretary in recent weeks as the Prime Minister prepares to unveil his roadmap for exiting lockdown this evening, the Mail on Sunday reports.It followed a succession of damaging headlines for the Department of Health over a failure to provide adequate PPE to frontline workers.These include title: coronavirus lockdown people infected staying home
story: THE coronavirus lockdown should be lted because workers are no more likely to get ill than people staying at home, a new study has today suggested.New York researchers found that two-thirds of patients had been following lockdown guidelines to stop the virus but had become infected anyway.Meanwhile, only  per cent of those who were infected had been working.The study followed , patients admitted to  hospitals in New York over three days - finding  per cent had been staying at home.Another  per cent had come from nursing homes - with just four per cent still using public transport.And cancer specialist Professor Karol Sikora, Dean of the University of Buckinghams medical school, told Thethe study appeared to show that lockdowns were only “of limited use”.He said: It is fascinating that it doesn’t seem to matteryou’re locked down or not. These people were locked down, but have a high rate of hospital admissions.Lock down is only of limited use. The risk factors for Covid are age, illness and ethnicity. These have more impact on what you’re going to get andyou’re going to be hospitalised thanyou are out and about as normal.Covid is targeting obese people and people with lung conditions. If we shelter those people who are vulnerable and ill then we can get more people back to normal.The study revealed  per cent of those who were admitted to hospital had underlying health conditions.The figures also revealed the worst affected group by the bug were aged between  to  years old.Boris Johnson put the UK into lockdown on March  - with Brits told to stay at home, avoiding public transport and public spaces.And the PM is today expected to make changes to the lockdown after seven weeks of the stay at home message.He will give the go-ahead for garden centres to re-open and guidance to employers so they can ensure a safe and strictly-controlled working environment for ing staff.But Mr Johnson will also reveal bigger fines for flouting the rules and -day quarantine for anyone arriving in Britain.Saturday’s official Covid- briefing revealed a further  people have died, bringing the UK toll to ,.The number of deaths among NHS and care workers has now passed  — hitting .It comes after leading experts last week flagged Britains coronavirus lockdown was futile and hasnt saved any lives.Researchers say that closing all non-essential businesses and ordering people to stay at home did little to reduce the number of Covid- cases across Europe.But the scientists, from the University of East Anglia, found that closing schools and banning mass gatherings did work to slow the spread.And Swedish researcher Dr Johan Giesecke blasted Britains lockdown as futile.The epidemiologist, who advises the World Health Organisation, said the UK’s death toll suggested imposing social restriction measures is not the best method of tackling the pandemic.Sweden has not forced a lockdown, keeping open many schools, restaurants and businesses while the UK went into a complete shutdown on March .Yet the most recent figures show that more than  times as many Brits have died of Covid- than in Sweden where there has been fewer , fatalities.An exclusive poll for The Sun on Sunday reveals only one in  workers wants Mr Johnson to start unlocking Britain today.Most are happy to be confined to their homes for a little longer to avoid the risk of coronavirus.But despite their support for continuing lockdown, eight in ten fear it could wreck the economy and potentially cost them their jobs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: international nurses day shine a light
story: INTERNATIONAL Nurses Day is an annual celebration of the crucial work and role of nurses around the world.It is especially important in  as nursing professionals continue to lead the frontline charge against the coronavirus pandemic.The annual event, which was first marked in , was created by the International Council of Nurses to mark the hard work of nursing staff around the world.Since January , the global celebrations are traditionally held on  May.This is to mark the anniversary of the birth of nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale.Each year in the UK, a service is held in Westminster Abbey in London.During the Service, a symbolic lamp is taken from the Nurses Chapel in the Abbey and handed from one nurse to another, thence to the Dean, who places it on the High Altar.But this year’s celebrations will be “extra special” because  has been designated the Year of the Nurse and Midwe, to coincide with the th anniversary of Florence Nightingale’s birth.It is also extra important as the world battles to fight the coronavirus pandemic.Nurses around the world have been vital to treating the sick and lting spirits during the pandemic.Here in the UK we show our gratitude to the wider NHS with Clap for Carers, every Thursday evening at pm.The public has been asked to “shine a light” on Tuesday to mark International Nurses Day and the th anniversary of Florence Nightingale birth.This will be done this year to recognise the efforts of nursing professionals around the world as they help to tackle coronavirus.The request is in recognition of the World Health Organization Chief nursing officer for England Ruth May has joined other leaders in urging people to shine a light from their window at :pm on Tuesday to mark the day.The call also comes from Professor Greta Westwood, chief executive of the Florence Nightingale Foundation, and Andrea Sutclfe, chief executive and registrar of the Nursing and Midwery Council.An image of the founder of modern nursing, as well as a message of thanks, will be projected on to her place of work, Londons St Thomas’s Hospital, from parliament.It will also be projected onto the British Embassy in Rome and the Italian Federation of Nurses between pm and pm.Ms May said of the event: “International Day of the Nurse is particularly special this year not just because we mark the th anniversary of Florence Nightingale’s birth, but because of the extraordinary work all those who have followed in her footsteps are doing in the fight against coronavirus.“I want to thank each and every one of our incredible nurses who are on the frontline in the battle against the greatest health emergency in NHS history. Their professionalism and skills are helping to save and rebuild countless lives.She continued: “It is a challenging but hugely rewarding career and I would urge anyone inspired by their example to sign up to join us and become a nurse.“I know how much the public’s support has buoyed my colleagues during this testing time. It would mean a great dealpeople once again showed their gratitude by shining a light for nurses this Tuesday.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris brits home revolt nations
story: The Prime Minister will today unveil his roadmap out of the lockdown, but his new slogan to “stay alert” has already sparked a huge backlash from other leaders.This morning the PM tweeted more detail about his new guidelines, insisting “this is how we can continue to save lives as we start to recover from coronavirus.”They say:However, after ditching “stay home” from the slogan, the leaders of the devolved nations have hit out at the PM.In a pointed tweet today, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon revealed she’d not been told about the new slogan in advance.She tweeted: The Sunday papers is the first Ive seen of the PMs new slogan.It is of course for him to decide whats most appropriate for England, but given the critical point we are at in tackling the virus, #StayHomeSaveLives remains my clear message to Scotland at this stage.Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford also hit out at the Government, saying the stay-home slogan has not gone away in Wales.He also demanded more cooperation with the UK, adding: When there is engagement, it is good, and it is helpful, and I wish there could be more of it.The PM’s new approach was also blasted by the Northern Irish First Minister Arlene Foster.She said: On the whole, the message is to stay at home.“We will say we are not deviating from the message at this time.It comes as the Prime Minister is set to warn the UK later today that the country is entering the most dangerous phase of the outbreak.The PM will urge “maximum caution” as he unveils his road map out of lockdown.Mr Johnson told The Sun on Sunday: “This is the dangerous bit.“We’re past the peak now but we’ll have to work even harder to get every step right.Mr Johnson believes that now the NHS has been protected from being over-run and families will be given greater freedom, the emphasis must change.People will be allowed to leave home more often but must stay alert to stop the spread of the virus.The new phrase came amid fears the “stay at home” message had been too effective and had made many families terried to venture out.It was dreamed up by Aussie strategist Isaac Levido, a former brains of the Vote Leave campaign, Ben Guerin, a -year-old Kiwi who title: 5 most common coronavirus myths
story: Advertorial most common coronavirus myths people are still falling forWith misinformation re – and dangerous – make sure you get the facts, not hoodsShareByDave Masters:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEveryone’s looking for the latest information on health, and how to protect you and your family from the coronavirus in these uncertain times. But with misinformation re – and dangerous – itaposs important to make sure you get the facts, not hoods. Hoaxes and health scares add to peoples’ anxiety at a time like this, particularlythey’re vulnerable or elderly. From the rumour that G is causing Covid-, to the myth that sipping water every hour stops you catching it, misinformation is everywhere.Scams can pop up on your phone too, with fake texts supposedly from the Government, promising financial help or warning of a fine for breaking lockdown. Digital Secretary Oliver Dowdensaid: The need for trusted information about coronavirus is vital. The UK media is performing a key role in getting this to people. “Misleading claims about the virus online could cost lives and we are working around the clock with tech firms to tackle these. We can all do our bit by being sceptical about what we read online. I urge people to follow these steps to ensure they’re not inadvertently spreading dangerous hoods. Here weaposve debunked five of the most common myths to help keep people safe.And below you can also check out the SHARE checklist for advice on how to spot fake news. And rely on trusted sources, not rumours, to check facts. For advice on health, that’s nhs.uk. For government guidance on work and money, it’s gov.uk  Myth: “If you go outside more than once a day, a £ fine will be added to your mobile bill.”FACT: Although the Government has advised people to stay at home, you can go outside for food, health reasons or work . Your mobile company wouldn’t be collecting a fine.Myth: “If you’re entitled to free school meals, send your bank details to receive financial support.”FACT: This is fake and you never need to send your bank details via text or WhatsApp.  Myth: “Hot drinks can help flush the virus into your stomach, where the acid kills it.”FACT: This has been categorically disproved. Myth: “The Army is making a giant lasagne at Wembley and delivering it to every home via drone.”FACT: This joke did the rounds via WhatsApp, but sadly for pasta lovers it’s not true.  Myth: “Lidl are giving away a £ coupon for completing a short survey.”FACT: Fake! Beware of phishing messages sent via WhatApp. Always check a retailer’s main website rather than clicking a link. Before you share... SHARE  Think before you like, comment or share online and use the SHARE checklist to make sure you’re not contributing to the spread of harmful content about coronavirus. Source Rely on official sources for medical and safety information. Check the facts about the coronavirus on the NHS.UK website and GOV.UK.HeadlineHeadlines don’t always tell the full story. Always read to the end before you share articles on coronavirus.AnalyseAnalyse the facts. If something sounds unbelievable, it might very well be. Independent fact-checking services are correcting  information about the coronavirus every day.RetouchedWatch out for misleading pictures and videos in stories about coronavirus. They might be edited, or show an unrelated place or event. Check to see who  is using the photo.ErrorLook out for mistakes. Spelling and other errors might mean the information is . Official guidance about coronavirus will always have been checked carefully.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson  is set to address the nation to detail his plan to ease the coronavirus lockdown restrictions. The Prime Minister will outline his road map to a new normality in his address to the nation at pm. Britainaposs route out of coronavirus lockdown is a five-stage plan staggered over the next six months. The Prime Minister has said the first steps will happen the next day “ we possibly can”. Ahead of the speech the PM tweeted out six updated coronavirus rules.The Prime Minister included the governmentaposs new slogan aposstay alert, control the virus, save livesapos in his tweet despite widespread criticism about its ambiguity from politicians and the public today.The previous stay home slogan has been dropped ahead of the unveiling of the governmentaposs plans to gradually ease the lockdown over the next few months.   Brits will be able to enjoy unlimited exercise from next week according to a draft -page plan to take the country out of lockdown. Since March  exercise outside the confines of the home has been limited to just one hour a day, though it is expected to be one of the first restrictions lted by Boris Johnson. The Prime Minister is also expected to allow Brits to sunbathe in their local parks - as long as they are apart from other people.Playing sports with their own household will be allowed and driving somewhere for a walk or run will also be ok under the new guidelines.For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.  Garden centres    One of the only things we do know ahead of the speech is that garden centres in England will be allowed to reopen with distancing measures in place from next week, according to a senior government source. Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford has said garden centres in Wales will be able to reopen next week. Mr Drakeford said on Saturday this is very much in line with Mr Johnsonaposs plans - so expect to hear something similar from the PM. It has been made clear that one of the most likely restrictions to be eased first is to do with outdoor activities, as there is less risk of transmission here than indoors. At the moment youaposre allowed to go for a run, walk or cycle ride once a day. As with outdoor exercise, outdoor working will have less chance of transmission that indoors. Building sites were never told to close under lockdown guidance - as long as two metres could be kept between workers - so the government is expected to make a renewed push for people toto work there. But there will be more guidance on how employers can protect staff amid concern from the unions that their members could be put in danger.  More guidance on the use of outdoor spacesThis will include open-air markets, high streets and cemeteries. Experts believe the virus does not spread as quickly in the open air so the government want to begin to look at other spaces which the public could access safely. Churches and other places of worship The Government could allow places of worship, including churches and mosques, to open for private prayer but not for gatherings of groups. The Muslim Council of Britain, the UKaposs largest Muslim umbrella organisation, is consulting its members before issuing guidance this weekend for mosques that are considering reopening. The majority of the mosques that we have consulted are of the view that they do not wish to open during Ramadan, an MCB spokesman said. We do not want to be the ones who cause harm to others. The Rt Rev Sarah Mullally, the Bishop of London, is leading the Church of Englandaposs planning for reopening its buildings. She said there would have to be signicant changes to key aspects of Christian worship for some time to come. I donapost envisage, even up to the end of the year, we will be back to our normal services. Weaposll have some churches doing things dferently. And of course, this approach will depend on the part of the country you are in. Being in Devon is very dferent to being in the centre of London. So we need to approach this based on our local circumstances, she said. There are some very challenging questions that weaposll have to face, not least about singing and about the receiving of Holy Communion. So the future will look dferent. But we want to continue to support people in their spiritual journey with their faith, she told the BBC. When we open our church buildings, we will still have to ensure physical distancing. Weaposll have to make sure people can wash their hands on the way in and on the way out. We are likely not to be able to use hymn books or service sheets or sing.  Libraries and council-run tipsLocal authorities will also be able to begin planning how to open libraries and municipal recycling centres. Some English councils have already begun reopening tips but with strict social distancing measures in place. New train timetables and more made available    As restrictions are eased there will no doubt be more people on public transport. Rail services are set to increase to about % of the normal timetable later this month as part of the gradual easing of the lockdown, it is reported.  Sources told PA there will be a gradual increase from May . Rail unions have been involved in talks about the safety of workers and passengers when more trains run.  Some areas might see aof similar services to a Saturday. Rail bosses and Government sources told the BBC that services will be increased to about % of the normal timetable - from about % - to ensure the railways are able to cope with a rise in passengers as peopleto work.  Plans for schools to reopen   The blueprint outlines a phasedof primary schools in England from the start of June, starting with Year . Pupils will have to observe social distancing as much as possible which could mean spread out desks and fewer children in a classroom at one time.According to the five-stage plan, a phasedof secondary schools in England would begin before the summer holidays. But, like most of the measures, it depends on the infection rate continuing to fall. More routine NHS services resumed The NHS has been adamant at stressing people should seek medical attentionnecessary, and not to worry about coming to AE because of coronavirus.

For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic,here He added: We need absolute clarity from Boris Johnson. Thereaposs no room for nuance in this. story: NewsopinionMark Steel: British governments clear advice on lockdown is clearly confusingWe shouldnt be surprisednext there is a live TV game show where celebs guess new lockdown rules while taking part in an obstacle course, hosted by Davina McCallShareCommentsByMark Steel:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionDavina McCall, potential host of a live TV show where celebs guess new lockdown rules " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSome governments around the world give clear advice as to what their population should do next, such as “Stay indoors for two more weeks”. But that’s boring. We’re lucky, because our government is much more fun. First they told us: “Changes will be introduced from Monday.” So one Conservative newspaper announced: “Hurrah! Lockdown freedom beckons.” Then they changed their mind and said nothing can change, then that there would be some change but they wouldn’t let on what it was. Next week they’ll make it a fun game where we have to guess the change.We could try going to the beach, thenwe get tear-gassed by armed police, we’ll know it isn’t that. Or there could be a  game live on BBC in which a group of ­celebrities tries to guess the new rules by asking a series of questions while clambering round an obstacle course. Eventually Davina McCall will ask “are we allowed to drink cider with our mates at a bus shelter ”, while ­clambering up a slippery ladder, then Matt Hancock will ring a bell and we’ll know that’s the new rule. With a similar spirit, when Boris Johnson was asked whether we should wear face masks, he said they “might help”. That’s the sort of clear decisive instruction we expect from a leader in a crisis. His hero Churchill was the same, when the Germans tried to invade he said: “I suppose sending some Spitfires up against them might help. I’m not sure really, it’s up to you.” At one point there was a report that schools could be reopened on May , or maybe not. This is ideal, because le is dull when you go somewhere and know for certain itaposs open. This way, parents can take their kids to school and have the excitement of not knowing whether they’ll take them in for lessons, or all get arrested for being outside at a school gate.

story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: We obey Professor Lockdowns rules, so why doesnt he Professor lockdown made a mockery of social distancing all because he had no control and only thought of himself, writes Saira KhanShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionShamed Professor Neil Ferguson was forced to resign after breaking own lockdown rule " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMy best friend Jo is like a sister to me. We’ve been mates for  years and she knows me better than anyone. So to know she’s had the worst week of her le and I can’t be there for her is heartbreaking. And now I’m angry too. Jo’s dad was poorly. He collapsed at home and an ­ambulance came. He spent two weeks in hospital, on his own, with Jo taking him clean clothes, which she had to give to a nurse. The family knew they had to stick to the rules to protect others. Then I got the news from Jo. “Dad’s gone to sleep for good.” Hearing my soulmate go through the most painful experience of her le, I felt helpless and frustrated. I wanted to hug her, make her a cup of tea and look after things while she came to terms with a le without her hero in it. But I knew I couldn’t jump in my car and see her. Just like she had sacriced those precious final moments with her dad and couldn’t say goodbye. But you have to think of others and be a good citizen. Only, hang on, it’s okay to get your lover around for a quick bonk. Professor Neil Ferguson, the guy who instigated the lockdown and lectured the nation on social distancing, happily stuck two fingers up to his own rules. Inviting his married lover around was an “error of judgment” he said.  We’ve all been falling in line with this top scientist. When he says jump, most of us say how high – and with or without a face mask, Prof  We trusted his expertise. He was the smartest we had. So what a slap in the face to we ordinary folk when he decides it’s one rule for him and another for us. It’s a daily fear for many of us with elderly friends and relatives – them being taken to hospital, out of reach and left alone. For elderly people too, the thought of being left to die alone is too much to bear. And then the added trauma of funerals, when you can’t even say goodbye to loved ones properly.
