title: nature makes swift return to argyll
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsBefore coronavirus restrictions were imposed, Argyll Bird Club provided monthly field trip outings around mainland Argyll led by experienced bird watchers.With most bird surveying suspended as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, the club is relieved it has now chosen a species which can be surveyed from home within government advice.Swts are slightly larger than swallows and have an all-dark plumage with a short forked tail. They feed on flying insects and spend most of their le in the air # including when they sleep # usually coming down to earth to breed. They are fast fliers, often chasing one another over buildings when they give a screeching call.Swts arrive back in Argyll in early May and breed in towns, villages and other buildings in Argyll. They spend around three months in Argyll, departing early-mid August to their wintering grounds in Africa.The British Trust for Ornithology’s Breeding Bird Survey indicates the population of Swts in Scotland has declined by around  per cent since . A similar decline has taken place in England and Wales. The reasons for the decline are not fully known but are believed to be related to changes in insect numbers and a lack of nesting sites as buildings are modernised.Argyll is at the north-western limit of the world range of Swts. Their distribution and numbers in Argyll is not well-known and the purpose of the Argyll Bird Club Survey is to try to find out the size of the breeding population and where they remain.If you have a Swt nesting in your building, or near you, or would like to take part in this survey further information is available at http:argyllbirdclub.org argyll-surveysFor more information about Argyll Bird Club, email Jim Dickson at Argyllbirder@outlook.

title: letters to the editor april 24 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A few weeks ago I launched an appeal on social media aimed at supporting nurses and medics at the Mid Argyll Hospital during this terrible COVID- pandemic.I was initially trying to find outthere was anyone locally who might be interested in dusting down their sewing machine to make a few sets of protective ‘scrubs’ to donate to the hospital. Within a couple of days the response was staggering.There were volunteers from all corners of Mid Argyll willing to sew, donate material and give freely of their time. Local businesses were also quick to respond with offers of material, pattern printing and transport for moving stock around.I am overwhelmed by the support and generosity of people in Mid Argyll. They have risen to the challenge and far exceeded my expectations.We have around  stitchers from Cairndow to Ardfern, and villages and towns in between, producing brightly coloured ‘scrubs’ using mainly donated fabric, scrap material and jazzy duvet covers. The first donation of ‘scrubs’ is expected to be handed over to the hospital this week and we are sure they will brighten up the wards.Our crowdfunding page, ‘Let’s Get Scrubbing for Mid Argyll’, was originally set up to buy everything to make the scrubs. It has broken the original £ target and we would love to hit the £, mark so please feel free to donate.I am overwhelmed and humbled by this experience and publicly thank the group team leaders, the volunteer stitchers, those working behind the scenes and the wider community for their support and generosity.My thanks is also extended to the following businesses who have helped in so many ways: MacLeod Construction, Kit-You-Out, Mary’s Meals, Top Designer, West Coast Motors, LG Upholstery, Clock Tower, Tarbert COS Thrt Shop, Premier Laundry, Ian Y McIntyre, Willie Leitch Sailmaker, Owen Sails and the Lithgow Family at Ormsary Estate.Nikki Thompson, Ardrishaig.Sir,The time will come when we are through the turmoil of this pandemic but as we work our way through it, I wanted to share a situation that reflects the actions of many.I was recently collecting shopping in Tarbert for registered vulnerable people and, as I was taking off my gloves before getting into the car, I was aware of another#s presence close by pushing a mobile rubbish bin. It was Damon. He saw me about to put my gloves into the rubbish bag in my own car and said cheerily #You can pop them into this bin here,you like#.I was so taken by that gesture. What an example of initiative, thoughtfulness and kindness. It summed up the incredible work of so many volunteers, co-ordinated by Team Tarbert#s Fiona, with Margaret co-ordinating prescriptions, and many others.Perhaps there is no better time for us all to reaquaint ourselves with Rudyard Kipling#s poem #If#.It seems to perfectly summarise humanity working at its best, in which, during this crisis, thanks to so many, Tarbert can walk tall. Stay safe.Peter Minshall, Tarbert.Sir,I write regarding the Argyllshire Advertiser edition dated Friday April  and the front page heading #Hospital prepares for Pandemic#.The article states: #No figures have been released about the incidence of coronavirus in Argyll and Bute# because the HSCP spokesperson said #we are following national guidance and due to reasons of patient confidentiality we will not be able to make public where in the Highland health board areas the positive cases are#.This statement is complete nonsense and shows either the HSCP in Argyll has not been privy to this information or they are just using the term #national guidance# as a smokescreen and an excuse and or sheer incompetence.No-one was asking them for patients# names and addresses, merely figures of those affected in a given area.The people appointed to positions of responsibility in Argyll and Bute HSCP are hopeless when it comes to joined-up thinking and accountability.All they will do is spin you a line and quote stuff like #national guidelines#, which is code for #I don#t have a clue#.Karl Edwards, LochgilpheadSir,Scottish and Southern Electricity Networksis extending the support it provides to those most vulnerable by expanding the eligibility of its Priority Services Registerto include customers at increased risk of severe illness during the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly , customers already receive additional care and support through SSEN’s PSR – a free, tailored service.In addition to those self-isolating or shielding for  weeks, customers are eligiblethey:Julie Walker, SSEN.

title: extraordinary kindness across our communities
story: The Oban TimesUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe United Kingdom is pulling together as one, with people from all regions and all four nations of the country helping each other through the coronavirus pandemic.As we all know, we must only leave our homeswe are key workers or cannot work from home, to do essential shopping and for one period of daily exercise.By doing this we will all help protect the NHS and save lives.Despite the absolutely necessary restrictions on our normal lives, people are being encouraged to help neighbours in need where possible. This has led to some amazing acts of kindness on every street, in every village and town across the country. Communities have never felt stronger. Today, we shine a light on just some of the people from communities across the country to showcase examples of ordinary people doing extraordinarily kind and helpful things.CASE STUDYGAIL REDMONDCHARITY that supports families has noticed a sharp rise in requests for help due to widespread redundancies.Gail Redmond of Via Wings’ in the County Down town of Dromore, in Northern Ireland, says the charity normally gives out  food bags a month to people in need.“But last week we gave out  already, many of which are going to people who are self-isolating,” she said.“One guy who contacted me on Friday, said: I have never asked anyone for help like this before. But I have lost my job and can’t afford to feed my kids right now.’ You could tell that he was absolutely mortied and so humble. So many people have lost their jobs.“We have told pensioners not to answer their door when we deliver, but one old lady insisted. We told her she shouldn’t be doing that, but she replied: I just want to say thank you’.“The older generation are so apologetic when asking for help, they all say: I’m sorry to bother you’.”Christian charity Via Wings is offering food deliveries and befriending to anyone who is self-isolating, elderly, vulnerable, an NHS employee, key workers, or those financially impacted by Covid-.Volunteers observe social distancing guidelines and food is carefully wiped down before being packed. Food and toiletry donations can be made at Eurospar, Supervalu and Vivo in Dromore and Tescosand Lidl in Banbridge.Via Wings works with local schools and churches, social workers, care workers and other agencies.“Working in unity is what our grandparents used to do, and that is what we need to get back to doing, caring for each other,” Gail added.“There is no ownership, we are just working together.”CASE STUDYNEIL MUSGROVEPicture# NEIL MUSGROVE SUBMITTED BY LEEDS CARESAN ULTRA-MARATHON runner is putting his best foot forward after several running events planned for this year had to be cancelled or postponed.Last year Neil Musgrove ran seven ultra-marathons and with none looking likely for this year he is running one in his back garden.He is doing a mile a day in his back garden according to his running watch and is hoping to reach his goal of the  mile starting distance for an ultra marathon by the end of April.For every mile completed, Neil is donating £ to Leeds Cares and hopes that friends and family will join in with the challenge at their own homes and donate after every mile completed.He said: “With no ultra-marathons to run I thought I’ll run one of my own. Any experience I’ve had with Leeds Hospitals in the past has been positive, I want to support all of our amazing NHS staff who are currently under huge pressure and working in extremely tough circumstances.“It is quite a few laps. All being well this takes me to a  mile ultra marathon distance. Yes it might get a little tedious but I am thinking of it as an ultra with a checkpoint, food and drink at every mile.“My young niece and nephew have already got involved and I’m hoping to get my own kids involved too. I’m sharing the challenge with my colleagues and running club team-mates so hopefully lots of us will get involved. Make it as interesting as you like. I am thinking about obstacles, singing, dancing, whatever. I would love itpeople joined in. The only rules are it has to be a minimum of one mile. It has to be fully within your own property boundary. If you don’t have a garden, special dispensation is given to use your street but remember the two metre rule.”All funds raised through Neil’s challenge will go towards Leeds Cares’ Support Your NHS Hospitals Appeal and provide vital support to frontline staff at Leeds Teaching Hospitals.This includes, paying for care packages, assistance with travel and accommodation where needed, as well as helping to fund other health and wellbeing initiatives to boost morale across the wards. He set a target of £ on his JustGiving page and has raised more than £ already.Leeds Cares is the official charity partner of Leeds Teaching Hospitals. The organisation supports NHS staff to deliver the best care for patients and their families, by raising funds for equipment, services, education and research.Leeds Cares works collaboratively with all of the hospitals across Leedsto identy charitable projects and causes.CASE STUDYSTENHOUSEMUIR FCHOME ADVANTAGE: Stenhousemuir players brought food directly to people’s houses.A FOOTBALL club initiative is supporting hundreds of families by delivering school meals to pupils during the coronavirus lockdown.With the season shut down indefinitely, Stenhousemuir FC set up its community help hotline in mid-March to assist the most vulnerable members of society as the effects of the global pandemic began to take hold.A -strong squad of volunteers was assembled in the first week to carry out everyday tasks like shopping or dog walking for those in isolation or for whom such activities would prove dficult. Since then, the number of volunteers has hit  although extra help remains welcome.Government guidelines mean the volunteers can leave their homes to help a vulnerable person and, with almost every volunteer already assigned to an inidual, more support is likely to be needed in the weeks ahead.The idea has been well received by those who live in the Stenhousemuir and Larbert areas and beyond, so much so organisers opted to branch out and ease the strain on mums and dads by collecting and distributing school lunches purchased by Larbert High School to youngsters stuck at home.Pupils from Larbert High and its cluster primaries are benefitting from the move.On just one day last month, volunteers delivered more than  meals to schoolchildren.Stenny chairman Iain McMenemy, who helped to organise the initiative, said: “We put out a few requests for further volunteers and the response to each has been really encouraging.“We’re doing one-to-one tasks for people like dog walking and shopping and we’re putting in calls to make sure they’re okay.“The advice was clear:you’re going out for your own shopping,you have to go to work,you’re going out for one bit of exercise oryou’re helping a vulnerable person you’re able to go out, particularly because some people have got nobody .“We have even had members of family from farther afield saying they have a relative in the area and they want to give you a call.“We’re still looking for volunteers as we’re only in week three and the smart money is probably on this being extended for three months. We’ve also expanded out to do school meal deliveries for a number of the schools. Carron Bathrooms got in touch and offered two vans so we now have three. On top of that, we’re doing deliveries for Falkirk Foodbank.”Though Stenny officials admitted concerns over the impact COVID- would have on the club itself, their focus has always been on the “health and well-being” of the community.When the community help initiative was first announced, Mr McMenemy wrote in a statement: “With the continuing spread of the coronavirus, Scottish football faces an uncertain future.“It is quite clear that there will be a signicant impact on football operations and finances and Stenhousemuir Football Club will no doubt be affected by this.“However, there are other, more important matters to think about. The coronavirus is a very serious disease that will affect thousands within our communities.“The health and well-being of friends, neighbours and members of our community should be our top priority.”CASE STUDYHARRY RAGLESSSTAR MAN: Steve in his dramatic outfit.A BOY with spina bida and his father are both doing their bit for the community # but in completely dferent ways.Harry Ragless usually spends  per cent of his time in a wheelchair due to his condition, which means his spine did not form properly in the womb and he has neurological damage to his legs and back and cannot feel his feet.But inspired by the efforts of -year-old war veteran Captain Tom Moore, which have seen him raise around £million for the NHS, Harry decided to raise money by walking with his frame and leg supports.The determined six-year-old from Oaksheath Gardens in Durrington, near Worthing, has raised £, and rising within days of his parents launching a fundraising page for his efforts # smashing his £ target.He said: “I feel really good. I was shocked.”His proud mother Selina Ragless said: “He has shocked us all. Because of his condition he tires easily but the other day he walked from our house to Vancouver Road, which is really far for him. We couldn’t believe it.”As word of his exploits spread, Selina said people were coming out of their homes to applaud Harry, who attends West Park School in Marlborough Road, Goring, when he went out for a walk.She said: “I feel overwhelmed to be honest. We owe the NHS so much they have been there for him since he was born and will be there for him for the rest of his le. If we can give something back, that is all we want.”In fact, Harry’s exploits grabbed the attention of Captain Tom himself # and his picture was featured on the Second World War veteran’s Instagram page.Harry is not the only person in his family who is raising a smile in the community.By day, his dad Steve is a warehouse manager # but during his daily walk, he dons his Stars Wars outfit to bring a bit of fun to the neighbourhood. The -year-old said: “I love it. From my own experience, I remember the first Comic-Con I went to in Birmingham and I saw all these stormtroopers standing outside, and I went into full fanboy mode.”The opportunity for him to get his own suit arose when a friend was selling theirs.He said: “When I finally put it on, I just felt amazing in it. I love seeing the looks and smiles, and people tooting their car horns and waving. It brings a few smiles in these very strange times.”Selina came up with the idea for him to wear it after they were put in lockdown, and during their walks around the estate Steve has posed for ‘socially-distant’ photos with some of the children who have come out to see him.In his spare time, Steve has donned the costume to a iety of events, including birthday parties, weddings and charity events.When the Connaught Cinema has done showings of Star Wars films, Steve has turned up in his gear to raise money for Sussex Association for Spina Bida and Hydrocephalus, a charity which has helped Harry.When askedthere was anything he wanted to say to the people who have donated so far to his campaign, Harry said: “Thank you.”To donate, visit justgiving. com fundraising selina-ragless.Nominate a community heroDo YOU know a volunteer who deserves to be recognised for making a change in their community The Prime Minister recognises one person a day with a Point of Light award.Read more or nominate someone at www.pointsoflight.gov.uk

title: argyll memories of victory in europe and a hazardous bike ride
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsTarbert girl Jean MacSporran was at school in Dunoon when the Allies declared victory in Europe on May , .Her daughter Liz Wyroslawska sent us a photograph of her mum, Jean Grantwho was brought up in Tarbert.Liz told the Argyllshire Advertiser: #She was sent off to finish her schooling in Dunoon as an older teenager. This picture is with her friends on VE Day celebrating.#Liz continued: #Mum, who is now  years of age, lives independently in Dumfries where she and my dad settled in .Jean MacSporran was a -year-old senior school girl living in digs during term time as Tarbert was too far to travel from Dunoon.She remembers that when she went at first there was a school unorm, but by  folk just wore what they could, usually hand-me-downs.Jean recalled: #On VE day itself, all the pupils had to register in their classes in school and they listened to Winston Churchill’s speech on the radio, then the Rector announced it was a holiday!#Jean and her classmates ran down to the waterfront at Dunoon.#Boats were all hooting their horns and it was very noisy and exciting. There was cheering and great joy that the war was over.#As for VE Day street parties, Jean doesn’t remember one in Dunoon # #it was too cold and they hadn’t food to spare#.But it was dferent that evening.There were celebration dances everywhere, and Jean got kitted out in her best dress to go to the village hall in Kirn. She was offered a lt there on the back of a motorbike from an older friend’s fiancé.She was wearing a silk slip underneath the good dress, which made the journey eventful. Despite holding on as tight as she could, Jean recalls nearly sliding off the motorbike several times.Happily, she made it safely and they danced the night away.After Dunoon Grammar School, Jean went on to #Dough School# in Glasgow and became a domestic science teacher.#My dad was George Grant,# Liz continued. #He had been in the th Ghurka Rles in India and Burma during the war, then went to Glasgow University to study law. They met in Kelvingrove, Glasgow and later moved to Dumfries where dad became town clerk and that#s where we were born and brought up. Dad died in .#Jean and George had three daughters, and now the family has expanded with eight grandchildren and the same number of great-grandchildren.Le under the recent lockdown has been dficult for Jean, as Liz explained: #The family are all over Scotland, so it#s hard for her not seeing them.But the Tarbert connection remains. #We still have strong Tarbert links,# said Liz, #as my son Stefan married a Tarbert girl, Yvonne, ten years ago.#PIC:Jean, aged , in the middle of the back row of this group standing near Dunoon Pier on VE Day. no_aVEday_McSporranJean pictured in Tarbert on avisit to her home village a few years back. no_aVEDayJean

title: teacher-urges-athletes-run-virtual-three-bridges-races
story: DESPITE the annual Three Bridges Races in Peebles being cancelled this year, families are being asked to go the distance for the NHS.Due to coronavirus-related restrictions, the whistle was blown on the mass event which had been due to take place on Sunday.However, Peebles PE teacher Richard Edge has found a way over that hurdle and says people can still take part.He explained: ldquoDue to the current situation and the subsequent cancellation of numerous sporting events, I have no doubt that many of our young athletes will be missing a little bit of competition."I would like to invite anyone to run the equivalent distance of the infamous lsquoThree Bridges Racersquo which is . miles .k.Entry is free but competitors are being invited to make a donation through a fundraising page for the NHS.The Priorsford Primary teacher says the route does not have to cover the bridges.ldquoIn fact I would only suggest running this routevery early in the morning or later in the evening," he said."Itrsquos very important that you adhere to the current social distancing guidelines.ldquoItrsquos quite good fun working out a route, so work together with older family members and create one that suits you."This year, however, there will not be any gold medals being doled out. ldquoThe winner will receive absolutely nothing ndash just the joy of being part of the first virtual Three Bridges," said Mr Edge.Families can also take part in a team event, the teacher explained.ldquoAs we are spending longer with kids, a family run may be fun, Mr Edge said. "A group of three or more people can do a run and finish together. Your family timed run should be titled lsquo bridges virtual family runrsquo."Just as would-be competitors are being asked not to drive to their start lines, they are also being urged to obey social distancing rules when out running.Mr Edge said: ldquoBe considerate to other people by keeping a minimum of m distance at all times when passing. Runs must be completed solo, unless you are running as a family."Entrants are asked to submit their finishing times online before May .Mr Edge said: ldquoSome people will have access to a watch that will be able to time the run and will be linked to something like Strava map my run. If you do not have a watch, use a smart phone with one of the running apps open and record it that way."Once you have recorded your run, you are invited to title it lsquo bridges virtual runrsquo, take a screen shot and email it to: Gwedgerichard@glow.sch.uk, including your name and year of birth.Mr Edge added: ldquoA selfie at the finish of your run would be pretty cool. I will then try and use the information to create final results.If you would like to make a donation to the NHS, visit this website.

title: virus-test-centre-opens-galashiels-key-workers
story: KEY workers in the Borders who are self-isolating can now be tested for coronavirus in Galashiels.A centre at Netherdale car park is open from todayuntil May .The facility, run by the military, will allow key workers who are displaying symptoms to be tested for the virus, with family members also eligiblethey live under the same roof.Scottish Borders Councilsays the site poses no threat to the public, adding that all equipment will be removed at the end of each day.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "I am delighted that we have managed to work with partners to quickly put in place plans to provide drive-through testing for key workers in the Scottish Borders."Irsquod urge any key worker who is self isolating, either because they themselves have symptoms of COVID- or because a member of their household is, to book tests."Testing is open to four priority groups, with those in Priority Group One already having access to NHS testing facilities.Priority Group Two includes "essential workers in critical national infrastructure fundamental for safety and security, and le-line services" Priority Group Three includes "staff directly involved in delivering other essential services" and Priority Group Four is for "staff involved in volunteering, or in nationally or locally signicant industry important to economic sustainability and growth".Key workers should visit this websiteto book their slot at the centre, which has been set up to support the UK Governments testing programme.

title: holiday-refunds---rights-get-money-back
story: Banks nationwide have blocked "billions of pounds" worth of refunds for holidays cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak.It is estimated that the public is collectively owed about pound billion from travel firms.Forced instead to turn to their banks for help, many customers have now been told they are not eligible for a refund.Heres what you need to know.Why arenrsquot travel firms giving refunds Consumer watchdog Which  recently revealed that  of the UKrsquos largest airlines and travel firms are illegally withholding refunds which should be paid to customers within  days.Instead, most customers have been offered vouchers or credit notes, with many complaining that they have been unable to claim a refund online, or get through to customer services on the phone to ask for their money back.Should I ask my bank for a refund Customers who have been refused a refund by travel firms and paid for their trip using a credit card can claim the money back from their provider under Section  of the Consumer Rights Act.Credit card providers are jointly liable with the retailer or trader for any breach of contract for misrepresentation, providing the value is more than pound and less than pound,.However, Which  has warned that some credit card customers have been told by their provider that theyre not eligible for a refund through the scheme.Others have been informed that their claim wonrsquot be processed until they have tried to claim the cash from the travel firm first, even though this is not a legal requirement.Customers are also able to claim through a process known as chargeback, which allows a transaction to be reversedyou are unable to resolve a dispute, including services not delivered.This covers all card payments and is a process agreed between financial institutions and the relevant card scheme, such as Mastercard and Visa.What are Mastercard and Visarsquos chargeback rights Mastercard said there is a chargeback right where firms have cancelled goods or services, even where this is due to government restrictions, insolvency or other exceptional circumstances.It is also validthe cardholder doesnrsquot wish to accept the firmrsquos offer to rebook or claim a voucher, but the issue should first be attempted to be resolved with the firm.Visarsquos guidance also states that firms should process a refund promptlycustomers decline a credit note or voucher, and cardholders do have a right to complain when goods or services are not provided.However, Visa does make an exception where firms have failed to provide a service due to a government-imposed travel ban, stating that this ldquosupersedes Visa rules on dispute rights.For this reason, Mastercard customers are likely to be more successful when making chargeback claims for coronavirus-related cancellations.If flights are cancelled due to closed borders, customers will still have a dispute right under both Mastercard and Visa, as EU-wide rules around refunds override the government travel ban, according to Which .Which banks will refund under Section  and chargeback Banks have said that they will assess each case inidually when it comes to refunds from firms only offering credit notes or rebooking a cancelled trip.This is what the major banks told Which  about issuing refunds:Where a provider has not met their legal obligations to the customer, Barclays will consider both chargeback and Section  claims, provided the relevant criteria are met.HSBC, including First Directand MS Bank, will allow a chargeback or Section  claim to be made for goods or services not received, but customers are encouraged to contact their airline first.Lloyds Group, including Halaxand Bank of Scotlandsay thata refund is not offered by the travel firm and a customer has proof of this, the bank can pursue a disputed transaction claim under scheme rules.Bankrsquos position is that every chargeback and dispute is dferent, and each claim will need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis with the customer to work out the best solution.Nationwidealso says each case will be looked at on a case-by-case basis because it depends on the type of good services being purchased and what the terms of the agreement are with the merchant.Similarly, RBS, including Natwestand Ulster Bank, said cases would be considered on an inidual basis.If a claim made with the merchant in the first instance is not satisfactory, customers can contact Santanderto raise a claim.,params: .pushWhere the merchant has offered the chance to rebook for free and or provide vouchers and the customer is not satisfied with this then Starling Banksays it would initiate a chargeback.If a merchant is not offering a refund, or are asking customers to contact their card issuers to process a refund, Tesco Bankcustomers can raise a dispute.The Co-operative Banksays thatcustomers tried to resolve the issue with the merchant first but there was no refund or resolution, the bank would look at each case inidually to verya dispute chargeback right existed. If a chargeback right existed but the cardholder accepted a credit voucher, this would not affect the cardholderrsquos original dispute rights. The bank would also not reject a Section  claim outright in these circumstances.If customers are offered a voucher or a chance to rebook, TSBwould typically accept the claims and each case will be considered inidually.If the customer is unhappy with the solution offered by the merchant, Virgin Moneywould consider the terms and conditions. If the alternative arrangements are not covered, a chargeback would normally be successful. Section  claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

title: 5g-mast-proposed-galashiels-council-land
story: PLANS for a G mast in Galashiels have been lodged with Scottish Borders Council .The applicationwould see the .-metresteel pole placed on the verge of the townrsquos King Street, on land owned by the council.Residents are now able to submit their views on the proposal, put forward by Harlequin Group on behalf of EE Ltd.Galashielscouncillor Euan Jardine said: "I believe it is important for our local economy that we are on level terms with other towns throughout the country in regards to G provision."It will also have some positive aspects for recreational usage and help to usher in advancements in technology that will change a lot of how we go about our daily lives."Mr Jardine added that he had not been approached by any residents about the application.Meanwhile, his ward colleagueHarry Scott told the Border he was not aware of the plans.Mr Scott said: "I would need to study the application and the circumstances around it before coming to any conclusions."The application, ref   C, can be viewed on the council website.

title: borders-homes-can-book-virtual-visit-auctioneer-bonhams
story: BORDERS residents have the chance to invite a world-famous auctioneer to look round their homes this week.Bonhams is delivering a free valuation service through video conferencing apps.And this week, households in the Borders are under the spotlight, with residents being asked to dig out paintings, jewellery, furniture and collectables.Bonhams Scotland managing director Charles Graham-Campbell said: "Wersquore trying to adapt and do these valuations in a way thatrsquos safe for everybody.Appointments are available from Tuesday until Thursday , am to pm.Items that can be assessed include paintings, silver, jewellery, ceramics, glass, clocks, works of art, furniture, Asian items, and collectables such as whisky.Mr Graham-Campbell, , said: ldquoWersquove always provided valuations where people have sent in photographs but we havenrsquot actually done a Zoom, Teams or WhatsApp virtual meeting ndash a video going round a house looking at objects.ldquoSo this is something new, itrsquos the antique world adapting to the situation we currently find ourselves in. Like other places, we are shut down at the moment."We canrsquot do a lot of work, but wersquore happy to try and help people where we can.Mr Graham-Campbell said it is more useful to see the house via video than to have photographs sent to the company.He said: ldquoWersquore quite used to handling photographs and working from photographs as a profession."It is always best to handle things, and there is always a caveat that the valuation is subject to further research.ldquoBut when we ask people to send in a photograph, they send in a photo of what they think is valuable, and what they think is a family heirloom."But so often when we go to a house, wersquore asked to go and look at a piece of furniture, for example, but actually itrsquos a small Chinese vase, sitting inside a cabinet, thatrsquos the valuable little item and theyrsquoll make more money than all the furniture put together. And they wonrsquot have necessarily known that.Even during the COVID- crisis, valuations continue to be required, Mr Graham-Campbell said.ldquoPeople take over something or inherit it and suddenly need an accurate insurance valuation and we can again have a look round and provide a stopgap valuation, until the times when we can do things in the correct manner, said Mr Graham-Campbell.ldquoThings that are being valued for a business need to be done to comply with their insurance every five years or something."Items need to be valued either for insurance or for probate, or executry purposes."Much of Bonhamsrsquo business is auctioneering, which has also had to be put on hold.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWith the situation as it is now, there are some people wanting to raise a sum of money and theyrsquove maybe invested in antiques in the past and theyrsquore using that as part of their pension fund.,params: .push"Theyrsquove maybe spent more on buying some paintings than putting into a pension fund and then theyrsquore wanting to realise those assets just to live or give something to their children who are having a hard time and not working at the moment.Scottish auctions normally take place at the Bonhams venue in Queen Street, Edinburgh, and these will also now be taking place online.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWersquore starting to do virtual auctions ndash wersquove done online auctions in the past, so wersquore quite used to doing them, but wersquore starting to work out how we can do more of them and then wersquore going to do a live auction behind closed doors."Wersquore hopefully going to be able to do that with maybe a live auctioneer and telephone bidders working from home and a clerk at a safe distance away."But the actual venue will be shut to the general public, and the public will be at home bidding away on their computers.ldquoThere are ways that we can work in a safe manner in the near future.To book a virtual valuation appointment, or for more information, email valuations.scotland@bonhams or call Charles Graham-Campbell on

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: borders-buses-puts-hand-sanitiser-vehicles
story: BUS passengers will soon have access to on-board hand sanitiser amid attempts to make public transport safer.Borders Buses is installing sanitiser pumps across its fleet as the coronavirus outbreak continues.Customers are already being encouraged to use contactless payment rather than cash, while drivers are equipped with personal protective equipment .In a bid to remind passengers to keep their distance from each other, tape is being laid on the floor of vehicles.A statement on Borders Busesrsquo Twitter page reads: ldquoWe would like to thank our customers for continuing to practice social distancing whilst travelling on our buses.ldquoWe have introduced some distancing lines on some vehicles to make it easier for you to safely move within the bus #StaySafe.A company spokesperson added: ldquoWe are committed to keeping our communities moving and served during these dficult and uncertain times.ldquoDelivering a safe and responsible bus service is our number one priority.

title: borders-gp-practices-stay-open-early-may-bank-holiday

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: jack-lowden-invites-entries-earlston-high-talent-show
story: ACTOR Jack Lowden has urged pupils at Earlston High School to take part in a talent competition.The former Earlston student starred in a video on Facebook this week appealing for entries to Earlstonrsquos Got Virtual Talent.Lowden invited pupils to submit video clips of themselves doing "something really cool and extraordinary".The -second clips should be sent through Show My Homework, he said, between May  and June .Giving examples of the talent being sought, Lowden said performances may showcase cooking, acting, singing, dancing, football skills or dog routines.When entries are received, judges will whittle them down to a shortlist and then the public will vote for the winner."There will be an almighty bonanza of a prize for the person that wins," said Lowden, calling on pupils to "have some fun".Lowden, who received an Olivier Award in , has appeared in films including Dunkirkand Mary, Queen of Scots.

title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy
story: A COUPLE will celebrate their th anniversary today by speaking to family over Zoom.Charlie and Evelyn Renton, of St Boswells, were married on May , , at Melrose Parish Church.With coronavirus restrictions in place, a traditional family reunion is not possible ndash but the pair have been looking forward to a virtual get-together.Reflecting on their long marriage, Mrs Renton, , said: ldquoWersquove been very happy and healthy and very lucky.The couple, who first met at Galashiels Academy, moved from Mr Rentonrsquos native Galashiels to the Republic of Ireland in .Mrs Renton, originally from Melrose, had qualied as a nurse in Edinburgh, while Mr Renton, , enjoyed a career as a textile designer.The couple have three children , three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.They ed to the Borders in , moving into their current home in St Boswells.

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: historic-borders-house-needs-20k-planned-re-opening
story: A STATELY home in the Borders needs pound, so it can re-open to the public in the summer, according to trustees.Paxton House, in Berwickshire, has been closed since the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March.But now the Paxton Trust is urging the public to donate by June  so the th century estate can open its doors again in July.Trust chairman Ian Marrian said: ldquoWe want to re-open as soon as itrsquos safe for all and wersquoll have to invest to ensure that safety."We cannot compromise on the conservation of our nationally signicant collections and the glorious natural landscape."But every day without income makes survival a greater challenge."Mr Marrian said the trust is also working "extremely hard" to try to gain a grant to cover the essential running costs for .He added: "We hope that,and when we re-open, we can with your help and attendance make these strange times a little happier.The trust, which has earmarked July  for re-opening, says it needs pound, by the start of the summer to maintain the property, as well as the childrenrsquos playground and gardens.The house was gted to the nation in  by John David Home Robertson, the last laird, for the populations "benefit and enjoyment".Its collection of paintings includes work by Allan Ramsay, Sir Henry Raeburn and Alexander Nasmyth.The house also boasts Scotlands largest collection of Thomas Chippendale furniture.

title: selkirk-firms-help-make-25-000-face-shields
story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. Hersquos looking forward to trying the cake.Jim was born in Gullane on April ,  but has spent most of his le in North Berwick, attending the local schools.He spent all of his career as a quantity surveyor and is a member of the local bowling club.He met Valerie, who is from Prestonpans, at the Pavilion dances in North Berwick, where the Scottish Seabird Centre now stands.The pair married  years ago.Morag said: ldquoWe were going to come over with the whole family and help him celebrate. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: nisa-store-steps-donates-1-300-charities-vulnerable
story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Now, the bowling club, which has about  members, is keen to see improvements carried out, with funding being sought to cover the cost of the scheme which has still to be calculated.A new metal roof could be put in place, with consideration being given to it blending in to the historic surroundings adjacent to Dirleton Castle.Two windows are proposed for the south side of the building to improve the lighting in the clubhouse, while three semi-mature trees could be removed. The trees, according to the design and access statement, cause a number of issues, including not letting light into the building, while their removal would also prevent damage to its foundations caused by the roots.Access to the clubhouse would also be improved through the resurfacing of a footpath, while a new lamppost would be erected to further improve the lighting.Thank you for reading this story.
