title: ben lowry most workers face hardship and many face ruin non frontline public sector unscathed and cant go if lockdown stays
story: Ben Lowry: Most workers face hardship and many face ruin, but non frontline public sector is unscathed — and that can’t go onlockdown staysPolice say they ‘sensitively monitored situation’ as images emerge of yet another large republican funeral gatheringNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionColumnistsBen Lowry: Most workers face hardship and many face ruin, but non frontline public sector is unscathed — and that can’t go onlockdown staysLockdown in the UK was announced on March  by Boris Johnson.By Ben LowrySaturday, th May , : pmUpdated Saturday, th May , : pm""If Stormont and national politicians keep telling us, sometimes in scolding tones, that lockdown is going to go on much longer, which means financial ruin, then perhaps they should take a symbolic pay cut, as business leaders have done. Also, much of the public sector is non frontline, yet unscathed by this crisis, while almost everyone  faces some hardship : User A week later, everyone in JPI Media,the News Letter owner, was told a pay cut was being imposed.No-one was surprised by the chief executive David King’s announcement. Other media groups had already done the same, and furloughedmore people than JPI did.In our case, no-one earning £, has had a pay cut, and above cuts were graduated all the way up to the top, with Mr King and the best paid executives losing %.No-one was thrilled about the cut but I heard no complaint. We respected the symbolism of the tiering, so that the best paid lost most.  " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...We all knew it was due to a health crisis. People would shop less and buy less, including newspapers It is now seven weeks since onset of lockdown. We have all learned a lot since then about Covid- and the impact of measures to halt it.One thing I have learned is a concept of Total Harm Minimisation, which means measuring the entirety of harm after a certain course of action. For example, forcing people to stay home might stop Covid- but cause other problems that are as bad or maybe worse. So you need to measure all costs and benefits.That will take years of careful examination of data. No doubt when results emerge not all the experts will agree on what they mean.My own emerging sense is that this first wave of the virus is nothing like as bad as it might have been, that this is not just due to lockdown – and that evenit was, the unintended consequences of lockdown might be as bad as the benefits.But that is only my sense [possible reasons why are given at the end of this article]. We all make our own judgments. My point in this column is the utterly uneven way that people are suffering from lockdown.This is nobody’s fault — no-one planned for restaurants to be destroyed and supermarkets boom.No-one decided that some people would be stuck in flats, and others in houses with large gardens. Butthis is going to go on and on, and some politicians almost scold us when they imply it will, then we need a new concept called, let us say, Total Harm Distribution.At present the economic harm distribution is wildly unbalanced.One long-term solution is to have a careful look at who is paid what.Most people think low paid key workers get a raw deal and there has been cross-party awareness of this. The  Labour government brought in a minimum wage, the  Tory-Lib one boosted it . It is easy to call for rises, but who pays for it  In an ideal world white collar workers, people like journalistsin an office, might face a pay trim to help fund manual workers.Butthis crisis goes on another subset of issues must be addressed. Leaders of private companies are taking big pay cuts, so perhaps public sector leaders and politicians will too  Many of the latter say lockdownis here to stay in the short term.I have written unpopular articles suggesting we pay politicians more , to attract talent. But there could be a temporary symbolic cut.And what about the swathes of the public sectorwho areunscathed by this crisis, while almost everyone  faces some sacrice  Few civil servants are frontline.In the same way that lists of essential businesses were drawn up, perhaps the same should be done for frontline NHS and key staff, who get a temporary bonus, while non essential public sector have a pay trim to help the national effort.There have been problems getting technology so that all civil servants can work at home, which is understandable given global demand on laptops, but it does suggest that some people have been at home for weeks on full pay. I put this to Stormont – they say that the “vast majority” are “working in line with latest guidance” It was political cowardice that Stormont went ahead with the teacher a pay rise, while sending out signals that schools will not reopen until September, and possibly only in a phased way even then.Memories are fading of the financial disaster in the s, when unions dictated pay, leading the UK to the International Monetary Fund.Meanwhile, appeal judges in Belfast last week put pressure on the attorney general to hold yet another inquest into a Troubles death where state failure is alleged .When people and businesses face ruin and when key workers are risking their health amid a shortage of protection gear, some of this taxpayer-funded expenditure is merely an insult.But some of it is an outrage. • Some reasons to be concerned at the grave harmof lockdown:There are, according to the Office for National Statistics, , unexplained excess deaths per week, in addition to , excess Covid deaths — a total of , excess deaths, which means deaths that above the average for a typical week at this time of year. It might ultimately be that the non Covid deaths are of people who are notably younger than the Covid patients who are dying, who have an average age of +, and many of whom were already gravely ill. We can speculate on about five likely types of non Covid deaths caused by lockdown: • Suicide .• Premature deaths from chronic loneliness of people who had little social contact before this crisis and now have none, or chronic stress of people who have lost jobs or are confined in an unhappy household .• Deaths from conditions that are not getting the treatment they normally do: heart, cancer, stroke.• Deaths from a depression plunging people around the world into poverty, reducing le expectancy. These latter deaths will take many years to show in statistics.• I asked the Department of Financeit was true thate some civil servants been at home for weeks on full pay with nothing to do  If so, is it a large number. Are there plans to change that  Andso, how will it change  When A Department of Finance spokesperson replied:“During the Covid- pandemic the vast majority of civil servants have continued to work in line with the latest guidance, either attending their workplaces safely or working remotely.“Civil servants have provided services and support to a wide range of people, including those members of society and businesses impacted by Covid-. Departments have redeployed staff to deliver priority work.“The Civil Service have been working over the past two years to change the way it works providing staff with the flexibility to work remotely. Services and working practices will continue to evolve in the future with more digital services coming online to serve citizens ensuring that staff can work efficiently from remote locations.”• Ben Lowryis News Letter deputy editor• Ben Lowry in : If we want better politicians we might have to pay them more• News Letter home delivery service is expanded—— ——A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. Putting up the age of retirement also means there will be less years for state pensions to be paid out.I worry at what appears to be the increasing use of the term ‘healthy over s’. What exactly does that mean  Few people in this age category I suspect enjoy perfect health, otherwise GPs across the land wouldn’t be advising them to take statins to keep blood pressure levels down. Women have been encouraged to take HRT long after menopause, even staying on it for leneeds be. These le enhancers, as some medical people appear to regard them, may be just the ticket. But how are we to know since the latter, statins, are relatively new to the people whilst HRT still attracts controversy Do either of these treatments increase longevity  We simply don’t know the answer to that question.Locking down the over-s, many of whom will still be paying tax to the Government, could be interpreted in many ways. I will take the kindly approach and suggest that the Government will need all the scope it has to get the economy back up and running schools will have to be re-opened and plans will have to be laid for the possibility of a future pandemic since the current one caught everyone by surprise and left the country on its knees. With the absolute necessity to get people back to work and paying income tax, the Government must have thought the oldies could wait and since many of them will have ious ailments it could be dressed up as ‘protecting them’. One Cabinet minister has said the whole thing ‘is to be based around consent rather than compulsion’.That’s fine, but it appears no one asked us first whether we wanted to be lockdowned for longer or left to do our own thing.I certainly do not want to be on lockdown for any more weeks than I have to because once you hit your s le seems to go by in a flash. It seems no time since my children were clinging to my skirts wanting me to play in the garden. Anniversaries and birthdays came and went with me so busy I scarcely noticed. The children grew up with me hardly noticing the years go by and then they were off to university. They found themselves wives, leaving us at home, on our own, wondering where all the years had gone. But still we felt young, still able to work and go on holiday.We hardly noticed our th birthdays, then last year it was the th wedding anniversary. We still have brothers and sisters and the only recognition of ageing is when the much older members in the wider family, the true older generation, pass on. title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: coronavirus  cases vale glamorgan lock extended
story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. What I do know is that the measures will definitely stay in force after Monday."With the Easter weekend coming up, Mrs James also reiterated the importance of abiding by the rules."There are signs that these measures are having an impact," she said. "Our decisions taken this weekend will impact our lives in the future. title: food vouchers sent   parents vale glamorgan
story: Though schools in the Vale have been closed for normal lessons since Monday March , many continued providing free meals.But it was later discovered that only a small faction of these were being claimed.Now the parents of the  Vale pupils in receipt of free school meals have been sent vouchers, which can be used to purchase food from a local supermarket.Arrangements were put in place for Tesco and Asda vouchers to be distributed and it is hoped a similar system can be established with other food outlets, including smaller operators located in the rural Vale.Parents will receive a pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn just two days staff working there have established a completely new system for administering free school meal provision so that no child goes without.ldquoSetting up this voucher system will help ensure a great many more children get the meals they are entitled to as only a small proportion were recently being claimed from schools.ldquoThe need to develop this system so quickly inevitably means there will be some fine tuning along the way.ldquoWith that in mind, I would ask parents to let us knowthey experience any glitches in the system and thank them for their patience and appreciation of the dficult circumstances our staff are working in.For more information on changes to school services, visit the Vale Council website. article_url   content_id   site_id title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. story: Irsquove also recorded online conversations with council leaders and police, and these are available to view on my page at any time. I raised some of the most common questions that Irsquom receiving from constituents, to find out how the authority is supporting residents, including:School provision: The Vale is using a hub system, with  schools providing services am-to-pm, seven days a week, for children of key workers and vulnerable children. Vouchers for free school meals are being issued to all who qualy every two weeks.Older shielding residents: For those without support from family and friends, the council has set up a Crisis Support Team to help with access to shopping, medication, and urgent temporary assistance. See the lsquoProtecting Vulnerable Peoplersquo section of the dedicated coronavirus page on the website www.valeofglamorgan.gov.ukBusinesses: There is a regularly-updated Business section on the councilrsquos coronavirus page, which should be the first point of call for all local businesses looking for assistance. Over pound million has already been distributed, and yoursquore encouraged to apply for support as soon as possible.Council staff: Staff are helping however they can some from non-essential services are doing waste collections, others are providing care. Itrsquos making a huge dference, and a recruitment drive for temporary care staff has also been a success.Volunteering: Local people are stepping up, and the Vale is supporting them via its Vale Heroes page on the website.Council tax bills: If you are worried about paying your council tax, get in touch with the department. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: queen busy windsor amid claim away public life months
story: The monarch has already been at her Berkshire residence for almost eight weeks, having moved there from Buckingham Palace in March, and spent her th birthday in lockdown on April .While following the guidance on remaining safe, she is still working, conducting a weekly audience with the Prime Minister by phone and receiving her daily red boxes of Government papers, an official said.A spokeswoman for Buckingham Palace said: ldquoThe Queen continues to be busy and will follow appropriate advice on engagements.The Sunday Times reported that the Queen is to withdraw from public le for months in what the newspaper said could be the longest absence from official duties in her long reign.The Queen, who is at Windsor with the Duke of Edinburgh and a reduced household, has made two televised speeches and one audio address to the nation since the lockdown.She made a speech to the country on April , when she delivered a message of hope, sayingwe remained resolute in the face of the outbreak ldquowe will overcome it.The Queen delivered what was believed to be her first Easter address in April through an audio message, telling the public ldquoby keeping apart we keep others
